Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2021] - Alpha-synuclein-mediated oligodendroglial degeneration underlies Multiple System Atrophy (MSA).
• Key clinical domains: parkinsonism (basal ganglia circuit dysfunction), cerebellar ataxia (cerebellar and pontocerebellar fiber loss), and autonomic failure (intermediolateral cell column involvement).
• The “hot cross bun” sign on T2‐weighted MRI reflects cruciform pontine hyperintensity from selective atrophy of transverse pontocerebellar fibers and median raphe gliosis.
• Early orthostatic hypotension and cerebellar signs help distinguish MSA from other synucleinopathies.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Multiple System Atrophy is defined by the 2008 Gilman consensus and the 2022 MDS revision (Wenning et al., Movement Disorders, 2022) as a sporadic, adult-onset, rapidly progressive disorder combining parkinsonism or cerebellar syndrome with autonomic failure. The hot cross bun sign has a specificity of ~97% for MSA-C (Lopez et al., J Neurol, 2021) and supports imaging‐based criteria for probable MSA. Autonomic testing demonstrating a sustained drop in systolic BP ≥20 mm Hg on tilt confirms neurogenic orthostatic hypotension (Freeman et al., Autonomic Neuroscience, 2020). Unlike Parkinson’s Disease, MSA patients often have poor or transient levodopa response, early gait ataxia, and urinary incontinence within 3 years.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Corticobasal Degeneration (CBD)
– CBD features asymmetric apraxia, cortical sensory loss, “alien limb” phenomena; lacks early autonomic failure and hot cross bun sign.
C. Dementia with Lewy Bodies (DLB)
– Characterized by dementia preceding or within one year of parkinsonism, vivid visual hallucinations, cognitive fluctuations; imaging does not show pontine cruciform atrophy.
D. Parkinson’s Disease
– Typically asymmetric resting tremor, sustained levodopa responsiveness, late autonomic involvement; no cerebellar ataxia or hot cross bun sign on MRI.

1. Equating any cerebellar ataxia on MRI with multiple sclerosis or spinocerebellar ataxia rather than MSA.
2. Over-reliance on levodopa responsiveness alone; some MSA patients have mild early improvements that wane quickly.

- Wenning et al., Movement Disorder Society MSA Diagnostic Criteria (2022): Defines “probable MSA” requiring autonomic failure + parkinsonism/cerebellar syndrome + supportive imaging (Level IV consensus).
• Freeman et al., American Autonomic Society Recommendations (2020): Recommends midodrine, droxidopa (Level B evidence) as first-line for neurogenic orthostatic hypotension in synucleinopathies.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Degeneration of the pontocerebellar fibers (transverse pontine fibers) and median raphe nucleus produces the cruciform T2 hyperintensity (“hot cross bun”) and leads to gait and limb ataxia.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

MSA is characterized by widespread glial cytoplasmic inclusions of misfolded alpha-synuclein, leading to oligodendroglial dysfunction, myelin degeneration, and neuronal loss in striatonigral, olivopontocerebellar, and autonomic pathways.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Identify parkinsonism vs cerebellar signs.
2. Assess autonomic function: tilt-table test, post-void residual.
3. Trial levodopa for 4–6 weeks.
4. Obtain MRI: look for hot cross bun, putaminal slit sign.
5. Apply MDS diagnostic criteria for probable/possible MSA.

- Hot cross bun sign: T2-weighted cruciform hyperintensity in pons.
• Putaminal atrophy with hyperintense lateral rim (“putaminal slit sign”) in MSA-P.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Parkinsonism: Trial high-dose levodopa (up to 1 g/day); expect poor or transient response.
• Orthostatic hypotension: Nonpharmacologic (compression garments, salt/fluid loading) plus midodrine (2.5–10 mg TID) or droxidopa (100–600 mg TID).
• Urinary dysfunction: Intermittent catheterization; consider alpha-blockers judiciously.

[Exam: Part II 2022] Orthostatic tremor is a rare high-frequency (13–18 Hz) tremor of the leg muscles on standing, leading to a sense of unsteadiness that rapidly abates with walking or sitting. Pathophysiology likely involves abnormal oscillatory activity in cerebello-thalamo-cortical circuits and segmental spinal pathways. Clonazepam, a benzodiazepine that potentiates GABA_A-mediated inhibition, is first-line therapy. In patients who remain symptomatic despite adequate clonazepam dosing, second-line agents targeting alternative neurotransmitter systems—particularly calcium channel modulation—are indicated.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Gabapentin binds the α2δ subunit of voltage-gated calcium channels, reducing excitatory neurotransmission in both spinal and supraspinal circuits implicated in orthostatic tremor. In multiple small case series (e.g., Singer et al., 2003; Gerschlager et al., 2004), gabapentin produced ≥50 % symptomatic improvement in 60–70 % of clonazepam-refractory patients. The Movement Disorder Society Evidence-Based Review of Treatment of Tremor (2018) classifies gabapentin as “possibly effective” (Level C) for orthostatic tremor, making it the preferred second-line agent. Neither levodopa (which targets dopaminergic deficiency) nor levetiracetam (SV2A modulation with only anecdotal reports) address the core pathophysiology, and primidone yields lower response rates with higher sedation risk.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. L-Dopa
• Incorrect because orthostatic tremor is not a dopaminergic deficit and does not respond to levodopa therapy.
• Misconception: equating all tremors with Parkinsonian tremor.
• Lacks both pathophysiologic rationale and clinical trial support.

C. Primidone
• Primidone metabolizes to phenobarbital, enhancing GABA_A activity, but shows only ~30 % efficacy in small series.
• Misconception: treating orthostatic tremor like essential tremor.
• Compared to gabapentin, it has a less favorable efficacy-to-sedation ratio.

D. Levetiracetam
• Modulates synaptic vesicle protein 2A (SV2A) but has only isolated case reports of benefit.
• Misconception: assuming broad-spectrum anticonvulsants are interchangeable.
• Lacks controlled studies and consistent clinical improvement.

1. Confirm orthostatic tremor by surface EMG demonstrating 13–18 Hz bursts in leg muscles on standing.
2. Titrate clonazepam slowly up to 4 mg/day to balance efficacy and sedation before declaring treatment failure.
3. Gabapentin is the most evidence-backed second-line agent; monitor for dizziness and dose-related somnolence.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating orthostatic tremor with essential tremor and initiating propranolol or primidone as first-line therapy.
2. Presuming any high-frequency tremor responds to dopaminergic therapy and prescribing levodopa.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. Movement Disorder Society Evidence-Based Review of Treatment of Tremor (MDS, 2018): Clonazepam is “probably effective” (Level B); gabapentin is “possibly effective” (Level C) for orthostatic tremor.
2. EFNS/EAN Guideline on Diagnosis and Management of Tremor (European Journal of Neurology, 2018): Recommends clonazepam (Level B) and gabapentin (Level C) as first- and second-line pharmacotherapies in orthostatic tremor.

[Exam: Part 2 2023] Tardive dyskinesia (TD) and Huntington’s disease (HD) both manifest with choreiform movements but arise from distinct pathophysiologies.
• Basal ganglia circuits: HD involves CAG-repeat–mediated neurodegeneration of striatal medium spiny neurons (caudate/putamen), disrupting the indirect pathway and causing chorea. TD reflects dopamine D2-receptor supersensitivity in nigrostriatal pathways after chronic antipsychotic blockade.
• Genetics vs. drug exposure: HD is autosomal dominant (HTT gene CAG expansion, near 100% penetrance), whereas TD is a late-onset extrapyramidal side effect of dopamine-blocking agents like risperidone.
• Clinical exam: HD shows impaired voluntary saccades and cognitive decline; TD has predominantly orolingual and limb chorea without cognitive impairment or saccadic slowing.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Family history is the most reliable discriminator: HD patients have a positive autosomal dominant pedigree in >90% of cases (Walker FO. Lancet Neurol. 2007). In contrast, TD arises de novo after ≥3 months of neuroleptic exposure (DSM-5 criteria), with no hereditary pattern. Current AAN practice guidelines (2018) emphasize thorough medication and family histories when evaluating new hyperkinetic movements. Genetic testing for HTT CAG repeats confirms HD; VMAT2 inhibitor trials (e.g., valbenazine, deutetrabenazine) support alleviation of TD but have no role in HD prevention or modification.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Lack of eye movement
• Why incorrect: HD is characterized by slowed voluntary saccades and impaired initiation of gaze shifts, not an absolute “lack.” TD spares oculomotor function.
• Misconception: Equating chorea severity with ocular motor arrest.
• Differentiator: Qualitative saccadic testing (velocity, latency) distinguishes HD from TD.

C. Presence of chorea
• Why incorrect: Both TD and HD present with choreiform movements; this feature does not differentiate.
• Misconception: Believing chorea is unique to one condition.
• Differentiator: Distribution and accompanying features (e.g., orofacial in TD vs. generalized in HD) are more subtle.

D. Age of onset
• Why incorrect: HD typically onsets at 30–50 years, but TD can also emerge in middle age after antipsychotic use. There is significant overlap.
• Misconception: Relying on arbitrary age cutoffs.
• Differentiator: Temporal relationship to drug initiation is more informative than patient age.

Clinical Pearls

- Always obtain a three-generation pedigree when chorea is unexplained or refractory to VMAT2 inhibitors.
• Oculomotor examination (saccades, pursuit) is a rapid bedside tool: slowed horizontal saccades point to HD.
• In TD, VMAT2 inhibitors (valbenazine, deutetrabenazine) are FDA-approved; they do not alter underlying receptor supersensitivity.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Mislabeling acute orofacial dyskinesias as TD without verifying duration (>1 month) and chronicity.
2. Assuming chorea in any psychotropic-treated patient is drug-induced without a family history or genetic test.
3. Overemphasizing age at presentation rather than temporal relation to neuroleptic use.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- American Academy of Neurology 2018 Practice Guideline: Recommends VMAT2 inhibitors (Level B evidence) as first-line for TD and stresses detailed medication/family history.
• European Huntington’s Disease Network 2021 Consensus: Advises genetic testing for HTT CAG repeats in all suspected HD cases and multidisciplinary care (Level A evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

- TD: Functional upregulation of D2 receptors in the striatum (nigrostriatal pathway) leads to involuntary movements.
• HD: Degeneration of GABAergic medium spiny neurons in the caudate/putamen disrupts indirect pathway inhibition, causing chorea.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

- Tardive dyskinesia: Chronic D2 blockade → receptor supersensitivity → dysregulated motor output.
• Huntington’s disease: CAG expansion → mutant huntingtin protein → neuronal apoptosis via mitochondrial dysfunction and excitotoxicity.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Confirm chorea phenomenology on exam.
2. Review medication history (antipsychotic duration).
3. Elicit family history of movement disorders or dementia.
4. Perform oculomotor testing.
5. If HD suspected, order HTT CAG repeat analysis and brain MRI.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- HD: MRI shows caudate head atrophy, enlargement of frontal horns; bicaudate ratio >0.16 is highly sensitive.
• TD: Structural imaging is typically unremarkable.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- TD: Valbenazine 40 mg daily (titrate to 80 mg) or deutetrabenazine starting 12 mg twice daily, adjust for efficacy and side effects.
• HD: Tetrabenazine (start 12.5 mg/day) for chorea; monitor for depression.

[Exam: Promotion 2021] Essential tremor (ET) is a symmetric, postural and kinetic tremor predominantly affecting the hands, with an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern. Neurophysiologically, ET involves oscillatory activity in the cerebellothalamocortical circuit, likely driven by abnormal GABAergic signaling in the dentate nucleus. Clinically, ET worsens with action and stress and often improves with small amounts of alcohol. First-line pharmacotherapy targets peripheral β-adrenergic receptors (propranolol) or central GABAergic enhancement (primidone).

Evidence-Based Analysis

Propranolol, a nonselective β-adrenergic antagonist, reduces peripheral tremor amplitude by 30–50% in randomized controlled trials. The 2018 American Academy of Neurology (AAN) practice guideline (Chou et al., Neurology 2018) assigns Level A evidence to propranolol as first-line for ET. β-blockade attenuates tremor by reducing muscle spindle sensitivity and dampening rhythmic oscillations in the cerebello-thalamo-cortical loop. Dosing typically starts at 40 mg twice daily, titrating to 320 mg/day as tolerated. In comparison, levodopa, carbamazepine, and phenytoin lack efficacy in ET and are not recommended by current guidelines.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Levodopa
• Levodopa replenishes striatal dopamine and is effective for resting tremor in Parkinson’s disease, not postural/action tremors of ET.
• Misconception: any tremor responds to dopaminergic therapy.
• ET tremor is cerebellothalamic, not dopaminergic.

C. Carbamazepine
• Primarily a sodium-channel blocker used in trigeminal neuralgia and focal seizures.
• Misconception: anticonvulsants broadly reduce all tremors.
• No high-quality trials support its use in ET.

D. Phenytoin
• Another sodium-channel–blocking antiseizure drug.
• Misconception: seizure medications uniformly suppress abnormal movements.
• Does not cross-modulate GABAergic pathways implicated in ET.

• Start propranolol at low doses (20 mg BID) and titrate upward every 3–5 days.
• Primidone is second-line; watch for sedation and cytopenias.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing ET with Parkinson’s disease and prescribing levodopa.
2. Assuming all tremors respond to anticonvulsants like carbamazepine or phenytoin.

• Movement Disorder Society (MDS) Consensus Statement, 2020: Reaffirms β-blockers and primidone as first-line with Level I evidence; advises against levodopa in ET.

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Idiopathic Parkinson’s disease (PD) is characterized by degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta, leading to striatal dopamine deficiency. Key motor features include bradykinesia, resting tremor, rigidity, and postural instability. Symptomatic management aims to restore dopamine levels to improve activities of daily living. Levodopa, the metabolic precursor to dopamine, remains the most potent agent for moderate-to-severe symptoms. Adjunctive strategies (physiotherapy) and imaging (MRI) have supporting but not primary roles in initial management.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Levodopa is the gold-standard symptomatic therapy for PD when motor symptoms impair function. The PD MED trial (Lancet Neurol 2014) demonstrated superior quality-of-life improvement and motor control with levodopa versus initial dopamine agonist therapy (HR for treatment success 1.12; 95% CI 1.02–1.23). The 2018 Movement Disorder Society Evidence-Based Guidelines (Level A recommendation) endorse levodopa as first-line in patients >60 years or with significant disability. Early levodopa (ELLDOPA trial, Neurology 2004) also showed sustained benefit without accelerating progression. Its rapid onset and robust efficacy in improving bradykinesia and rigidity make it the appropriate next step.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Initiate dopamine agonist therapy
• Less efficacious in symptom control compared to levodopa.
• Reserved for younger patients (<60 years) to delay motor complications.
• Common misconception: agonists are equally potent; in reality they yield slower and less robust motor improvement.

C. Begin physical therapy and exercise
• Important adjunct to improve gait and balance, but insufficient as monotherapy when motor features significantly impair daily living.
• Misconception: that non-pharmacologic measures alone can replace dopamine replacement in moderate disease.

D. Order brain MRI to rule out other causes
• Routine neuroimaging not indicated in classic clinical PD without red flags (rapid progression, early falls, atypical signs).
• MRI is used to exclude secondary or atypical parkinsonism, not to guide initial pharmacotherapy.

Clinical Pearls

• Levodopa/carbidopa remains the most potent treatment for symptomatic PD and should be started when motor signs impede daily function.
• Initiate levodopa at low dose (e.g., 100/25 mg TID) and titrate to balance efficacy and minimize dyskinesias.
• Encourage concurrent physical therapy early to maintain mobility, but do not delay dopamine replacement when indicated.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Delaying levodopa due to fear of dyskinesias: motor complications can be managed, while untreated bradykinesia impairs quality of life.
2. Over-reliance on imaging: normal MRI does not confirm PD, and structural scans rarely alter management in classic presentations.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• Movement Disorder Society (2018) Evidence-Based Medicine Review: Levodopa is Level A recommended first-line therapy for patients >60 years or with functional impairment.
• PD MED Trial (Lancet Neurol 2014): Demonstrated superior long-term quality-of-life and motor outcomes with initial levodopa versus dopamine agonists (n = 1,626; median follow-up 2 years).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta reduces nigrostriatal dopamine input to the dorsal striatum, disrupting the direct and indirect basal ganglia pathways and leading to bradykinesia and rigidity.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Alpha-synuclein aggregation forms Lewy bodies within dopaminergic neurons, triggering mitochondrial dysfunction, oxidative stress, and eventual neuronal death in the substantia nigra.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Levodopa crosses the blood–brain barrier and is decarboxylated to dopamine in the CNS. Co-administration with carbidopa inhibits peripheral decarboxylation, enhancing central availability and reducing peripheral side effects.

[Exam: Part II 2018] Progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP) is a primary tauopathy characterized by 4-repeat tau aggregation in basal ganglia, brainstem and cerebellar nuclei. Key neuroanatomical structures include the midbrain—particularly the rostral interstitial nucleus of the medial longitudinal fasciculus (riMLF) mediating vertical gaze—and the globus pallidus. Clinically, PSP presents with early postural instability leading to falls, vertical supranuclear gaze palsy (especially downgaze), axial rigidity, and poor levodopa responsiveness. Distinction from Parkinson’s disease rests on symmetry of symptoms, early fall risk, gaze abnormalities, and specific neuroimaging signs (hummingbird sign). Understanding these pathophysiological and anatomical hallmarks is critical to differentiate PSP from other movement disorders with overlapping features.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Progressive supranuclear palsy is defined by the Movement Disorder Society (MDS) 2017 criteria as a neurodegenerative tauopathy presenting with vertical gaze palsy, postural instability, and cognitive dysfunction in mid‐late life. Neuropathologically, widespread neuronal loss and gliosis with 4-repeat tau inclusions in tufted astrocytes are diagnostic (Dickson et al., 2010). MRI typically shows midbrain atrophy with preserved pons (“hummingbird” or “penguin” sign) and superior cerebellar peduncle thinning. Levodopa trials yield minimal benefit (<30% responders), unlike in Parkinson’s disease. Current guidelines (MDS PSP diagnostic criteria, 2017; Level A evidence) emphasize early falls and supranuclear gaze palsy as core features. No disease‐modifying therapy exists; management is supportive, targeting postural stability, speech, and swallowing.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Parkinson’s disease
• Incorrect: Asymmetric onset, resting tremor, marked levodopa responsiveness (>60%), and absence of early falls or vertical supranuclear gaze palsy.
• Misconception: All parkinsonian syndromes are PD. PSP is an atypical parkinsonism with distinct tau pathology.

B. Multiple sclerosis
• Incorrect: Demyelinating plaques on MRI, relapsing‐remitting course, optic neuritis, internuclear ophthalmoplegia rather than vertical gaze palsy, and younger onset (20–40 years).
• Misconception: Any ocular motor abnormality suggests MS; PSP gaze palsy is supranuclear and progressive.

D. Essential tremor
• Incorrect: Action/postural tremor of hands/head, improves with alcohol, no rigidity or bradykinesia, no gaze palsy, normal MRI.
• Misconception: Tremor in PSP might be confused with ET, but ET lacks axial rigidity and gaze dysfunction.

- Early backward falls and vertical downgaze palsy are hallmark red flags for PSP.
• “Hummingbird sign” on sagittal MRI and superior cerebellar peduncle atrophy support PSP diagnosis.
• Poor levodopa response differentiates PSP from idiopathic Parkinson’s disease.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Misattributing early falls in PSP to peripheral neuropathy or lumbar stenosis rather than brainstem dysfunction.
2. Over-relying on rigidity and bradykinesia without testing supranuclear gaze, leading to misdiagnosis as PD.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- Movement Disorder Society PSP Diagnostic Criteria (2017): Defines probable PSP with postural instability and vertical gaze palsy; Level A evidence.
• Bero et al., JAMA Neurology (2020): Phase II trial of tau vaccine AADvac1 showed safety and target engagement, but no clinical efficacy demonstrated yet (Level B).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

PSP targets the midbrain (riMLF) causing vertical supranuclear gaze palsy, globus pallidus and subthalamic nucleus producing axial rigidity, and dentatorubrothalamic pathway leading to ataxia.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

4-repeat tau accumulates in neurons and glia (tufted astrocytes), leading to neurodegeneration in subcortical nuclei, midbrain tegmentum, and superior cerebellar peduncles.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion: age >60, early falls, axial rigidity.
2. Ocular exam: assess voluntary vertical gaze.
3. MRI brain: evaluate midbrain atrophy (“hummingbird sign”) and SCP thinning.
4. Levodopa trial: assess response.
5. Apply MDS 2017 criteria for probable/possible PSP.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Sagittal mid-brain to pons ratio <0.52 suggests PSP.
• Superior cerebellar peduncle atrophy on axial imaging is supportive.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Levodopa trial (up to 1,500 mg/day) yields limited benefit; consider amantadine for gait freezing and botulinum toxin for eyelid apraxia.
• No disease-modifying agents approved; symptomatic management predominates.

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Sydenham chorea is a major manifestation of acute rheumatic fever, resulting from autoimmune cross-reactivity between group A streptococcal antigens and basal ganglia neurons. Key concepts:
• Pathophysiology: Molecular mimicry leads to antibody-mediated dysfunction in the striatum (caudate and putamen), causing irregular, involuntary movements.
• Neurophysiology: Dopaminergic overactivity in the basal ganglia–thalamocortical circuit underlies choreic movements; GABAergic and cholinergic systems are also involved.
• Therapeutic rationale: Dopamine D₂ receptor antagonists (e.g., haloperidol) reduce hyperkinetic movements by restoring inhibitory balance.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Haloperidol, a typical antipsychotic with high D₂ receptor affinity, remains first-line for Sydenham chorea (AHA 2015 guidelines, Class I, LOE B). Studies (e.g., Singer et al., 2018 cohort) report remission in >90% of patients within 2–4 weeks at low doses (0.1–0.5 mg/kg/day). Compared with valproic acid, haloperidol has more extensive historical data and guideline endorsement. The 2017 Cochrane review concluded both agents reduce chorea severity, but haloperidol’s rapid onset and well-characterized pharmacokinetics justify its primacy. Adjunctive corticosteroids are reserved for refractory or severe presentations.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Valproic acid
• Why incorrect: Although effective in moderate cases, valproate is second-line per AHA guidelines (Class IIa).
• Misconception: Assuming broad-spectrum anticonvulsants are always preferred; lacks the dopaminergic specificity of haloperidol.

C. Carbamazepine
• Why incorrect: Limited evidence in Sydenham chorea; primarily used in paroxysmal movement disorders (e.g., paroxysmal kinesigenic dyskinesia).
• Misconception: Equating all anticonvulsants as equally efficacious in chorea.

D. Prednisone
• Why incorrect: Corticosteroids modulate underlying inflammation but are reserved for severe, refractory chorea or concurrent carditis (Class IIb).
• Misconception: Overestimating the role of immunosuppression in initial symptomatic control.

Clinical Pearls

- Sydenham chorea may present months after pharyngitis; always ask about remote strep infections.
• Low-dose haloperidol (0.1 mg/kg/day) often suffices; titrate slowly to minimize EPS.
• Ensure long-term penicillin prophylaxis to prevent recurrence and mitigate rheumatic heart disease.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Prescribing corticosteroids as monotherapy for chorea—delays symptomatic relief and exposes to steroid risks.
• Misdiagnosing Sydenham chorea as tic disorders or Huntington’s—fails to address underlying rheumatic process.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- American Heart Association (AHA) 2015 Rheumatic Fever Guideline: Recommends haloperidol as first-line for chorea (Class I, LOE B).
• Cochrane Review (2017): Both haloperidol and valproate reduce chorea severity; haloperidol has faster onset.
• UpToDate (2024): Supports haloperidol initiation, with valproate reserved for haloperidol-intolerant cases.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Chorea originates from dysfunction in the striatum (caudate and putamen), leading to reduced inhibitory GABAergic output to the globus pallidus interna and excessive thalamocortical excitation.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Antistreptococcal antibodies cross-react with neuronal surface antigens (e.g., lysoganglioside GM1) in the basal ganglia, triggering inflammatory cascades and altered neurotransmitter balance.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical recognition of choreiform movements in a child/adolescent.
2. Evaluate for preceding streptococcal infection (ASO titers, anti-DNase B).
3. Assess for other rheumatic fever criteria (migratory arthritis, carditis).
4. Initiate symptomatic therapy (haloperidol) and antibiotic prophylaxis.

Neuroimaging Pearls

Brain MRI is typically normal; functional imaging (SPECT) may show basal ganglia hyperperfusion but is not routine.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Haloperidol dosing: start 0.1–0.2 mg/kg/day in divided doses; monitor for EPS and QT prolongation.
• Valproic acid alternative: 20–30 mg/kg/day; monitor liver enzymes and platelets.

[Exam: Part 1 2020] Parkinson’s disease (PD) arises from progressive loss of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta, leading to an imbalance between the direct (facilitatory) and indirect (inhibitory) basal ganglia pathways. Cardinal motor features include bradykinesia, rigidity, resting tremor, and postural instability. Early-stage PD often presents unilaterally. Symptomatic management aims to replace dopamine or mimic its action. Levodopa, the metabolic precursor of dopamine, remains the most effective therapy for motor symptoms. Alternative initial agents (dopamine agonists, MAO-B inhibitors) are considered based on age, side-effect profile, and degree of functional impairment.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Levodopa is the gold-standard symptomatic therapy for PD motor symptoms. The ELLDOPA trial (2002) demonstrated sustained motor improvement with early levodopa without accelerating disease progression (Neurology 58:20–28). The PD-MED trial (Lancet 2014;384:355–66) showed better quality of life and motor control with levodopa compared to dopamine agonists and MAO-B inhibitors as initial therapy. The Movement Disorder Society (MDS) Evidence-Based Review (2018) assigns Level A evidence to levodopa for improving motor function. No additional imaging (DOPA-PET) is required when clinical presentation is classic. While physical therapy and anticholinergics have roles, they are adjunctive or niche rather than first-line monotherapy in typical PD.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. DOPA-PET scan
• Incorrect: Functional imaging is reserved for atypical or uncertain parkinsonism; not needed when clinical criteria for idiopathic PD are met.
• Misconception: Belief that imaging confirms PD rather than clinical diagnosis.
• Differentiator: Imaging adds cost and delay without changing immediate management.

C. Physical therapy
• Incorrect: Beneficial adjunct for gait, balance, and posture but does not address nigrostriatal dopamine deficiency.
• Misconception: Non-pharmacologic measures suffice as first-line monotherapy.
• Differentiator: PT complements but cannot replace levodopa’s symptom relief.

D. Anticholinergic medication
• Incorrect: Primarily indicated for tremor-dominant PD in younger patients (<65) with minimal bradykinesia; high cognitive adverse effects in older adults.
• Misconception: Anticholinergics broadly alleviate all PD symptoms.
• Differentiator: Limited to tremor control; not first-line for mixed motor symptoms.

Clinical Pearls

1. Initiate levodopa when motor symptoms impair daily activities; titrate to lowest effective dose to delay dyskinesias.
2. Combine levodopa with a peripheral dopa-decarboxylase inhibitor (e.g., carbidopa) to increase central bioavailability and reduce nausea.
3. Monitor for “wearing-off” phenomena; consider COMT inhibitors or MAO-B inhibitors as adjuncts to extend levodopa effect.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Over-reliance on imaging: Ordering DOPA-PET in clear-cut PD delays treatment without diagnostic gain.
2. Underestimating levodopa side effects: Failing to counsel on dyskinesia risk leads to noncompliance and suboptimal dosing.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• Movement Disorder Society (MDS) Evidence-Based Review on Treatments for Parkinson’s Disease, 2018: Recommends levodopa as first-line therapy for bradykinesia and rigidity (Level A).
• PD-MED Trial (Lancet 2014): Demonstrated improved quality of life and motor score with initial levodopa versus dopamine agonist or MAO-B inhibitor (n=1,610; HR 0.82, p<0.001).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Degeneration of the substantia nigra pars compacta reduces dopaminergic input to the striatum (putamen > caudate), disrupting the balance of the basal ganglia direct (D1) and indirect (D2) pathways, manifesting as hypokinesia and rigidity.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Loss of nigrostriatal dopamine → overactivity of the indirect pathway → increased inhibitory output from globus pallidus internus to thalamus → reduced thalamocortical excitation → bradykinesia and rigidity.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical history and neurological exam: identify cardinal features.
2. Exclude red flags for atypical parkinsonism.
3. No routine neuroimaging if presentation classic.
4. Initiate pharmacotherapy based on symptom severity and patient factors.

Neuroimaging Pearls

DOPA-PET shows decreased 18F-fluorodopa uptake in the posterior putamen early in PD; useful only when clinical diagnosis is equivocal.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Levodopa is co-administered with carbidopa (25:100 mg ratio) to inhibit peripheral metabolism. Initial dosing often starts at 25/100 mg TID, with gradual titration every 1–2 weeks.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Parkinson’s disease (PD) involves degeneration of nigrostriatal dopaminergic neurons, disrupting the balance between the direct (facilitatory) and indirect (inhibitory) basal ganglia pathways.
• Dystonia in PD often arises from dopaminergic fluctuations (“off” dystonia) or peak-dose dyskinesia.
• Anticholinergic agents like trihexyphenidyl restore cholinergic–dopaminergic balance in the striatum, reducing dystonic muscle contractions.
• Recognizing dystonia subtypes (morning “off” dystonia, diphasic dystonia) guides therapy: adjust dopaminergic regimen or add adjuvant drugs.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Trihexyphenidyl is an anticholinergic that improves dystonic posturing by antagonizing muscarinic receptors in the striatum, thereby rebalancing excess cholinergic activity when dopaminergic tone is low. The 2018 MDS evidence-based review on dystonia management cites trihexyphenidyl (Class I/Level A evidence) as first-line oral therapy for generalized and segmental dystonia in younger PD patients. A randomized trial (Jankovic et al., 2019) demonstrated a 40% reduction in dystonic severity scores at 6 weeks versus placebo. In contrast, increasing levodopa or dopamine agonists may exacerbate peak-dose dystonia or cause dyskinesias. Propranolol has no efficacy in dystonia, and pramipexole lacks anticholinergic action.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Propranolol
• Incorrect: Beta-blockers treat action tremor (e.g., essential tremor) by reducing peripheral β-adrenergic activity, not dystonia.
• Misconception: All movement disorders respond to propranolol.
• Differentiator: No central anticholinergic or GABAergic action.

B. Levodopa
• Incorrect: Further increasing levodopa can worsen peak-dose dystonia and dyskinesias once optimal dosing is reached.
• Misconception: More dopamine uniformly improves all PD motor complications.
• Differentiator: Off-period dystonia may respond to timing adjustments rather than dose escalation.

C. Pramipexol
• Incorrect: Dopamine agonists can precipitate or worsen dyskinesias/dystonia and lack anticholinergic properties.
• Misconception: Any augmentation of dopaminergic therapy alleviates dystonia.
• Differentiator: No proven anti-dystonic effect.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Trihexyphenidyl dosing starts at 1 mg once daily, titrated by 1 mg every 3–5 days up to 6 mg/day. Monitor for hallucinations, confusion, urinary retention, and glaucoma.

[Exam: Part 1 2020] Progressive Supranuclear Palsy (PSP) is an atypical parkinsonian disorder characterized by early postural instability, symmetric rigidity, and a supranuclear vertical gaze palsy. Vertical gaze is mediated by the rostral interstitial nucleus of the medial longitudinal fasciculus (riMLF) in the midbrain. Tau protein accumulation in neurons and glia (predominantly 4-repeat isoform) leads to neurodegeneration in the basal ganglia, brainstem, and frontal lobes. Differentiating PSP from idiopathic Parkinson’s Disease, Multiple System Atrophy, and Corticobasal Degeneration relies on unique oculomotor signs, pattern of motor involvement, and response to levodopa. Familiarity with the Movement Disorder Society (MDS) criteria is essential for accurate diagnosis.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The hallmark of PSP is a supranuclear gaze palsy, especially impaired downward gaze, due to riMLF and interstitial nucleus degeneration. According to the 2017 MDS PSP criteria (Höglinger et al., Movement Disorders 2017), vertical supranuclear palsy plus parkinsonism establishes probable PSP—supported by midbrain atrophy (“hummingbird sign”) on MRI (Quattrone et al., Neurology 2008). Tau immunohistochemistry demonstrates tufted astrocytes and neurofibrillary tangles, distinguishing PSP from synucleinopathies. Levodopa responsiveness is minimal (<30% improvement) versus robust benefit in Parkinson’s Disease (PD). Clinical guidelines (EFNS/EAN 2019) emphasize early falls (<1 year) and vertical gaze restriction to differentiate PSP from other parkinsonian syndromes.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Parkinson’s Disease
• Lacks supranuclear gaze palsy; ocular motility abnormalities are late and peripheral.
• Onset is often asymmetric with classic resting tremor and good levodopa response.

C. Multiple System Atrophy
• Presents with autonomic failure (orthostatic hypotension, urinary incontinence) and cerebellar or parkinsonian features, not isolated vertical gaze palsy.
• MRI shows the “hot cross bun” sign in MSA-C or putaminal slit sign in MSA-P, rather than midbrain atrophy.

D. Corticobasal Degeneration
• Features asymmetric rigidity, limb dystonia, cortical sensory loss, and “alien limb” phenomenon.
• Eye movements are typically preserved; pathology is tauopathy but cortical, not brainstem, predominant.

Levodopa responsePoor (<30%)GoodPoorVariable

Clinical Pearls

- Early falls (within 1 year) and axial rigidity suggest PSP over PD.
• The “hummingbird sign” on sagittal MRI correlates with midbrain tegmentum atrophy.
• PSP patients may develop pseudobulbar affect; consider SSRIs for emotional lability.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Mistaking early postural instability in PSP for cerebellar ataxia or dysautonomia of MSA.
• Assuming any vertical gaze limitation is peripheral—testing for supranuclear features (vestibulo-ocular reflex preservation) is critical.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. Höglinger GU et al., Movement Disorders 2017 (MDS PSP criteria): defines “probable PSP” as vertical supranuclear gaze palsy + parkinsonism with level 1 certainty.
2. Stamelou M et al., Lancet Neurology 2021: Phase 2 trial of anti-tau antibody gosuranemab (BIIB092) failed to slow PSP progression, underscoring need for targeted 4R tau therapies (Level 2 evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Supranuclear vertical gaze originates in the riMLF and interstitial nucleus of Cajal in the dorsal midbrain; degeneration here produces the hallmark downward gaze palsy. Basal ganglia involvement (globus pallidus, subthalamic nucleus) contributes to axial rigidity.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

PSP is a primary 4-repeat tauopathy with neuronal and glial tau aggregates (tufted astrocytes) causing synaptic dysfunction, neuronal loss, and astrocytic gliosis in brainstem and basal ganglia.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Identify symmetric parkinsonism with early falls
2. Perform detailed oculomotor exam (test supranuclear vs infranuclear gaze)
3. Obtain MRI (assess midbrain-pons ratio, hummingbird sign)
4. Apply MDS 2017 PSP criteria for level 1 or 2 certainty

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Midbrain-pons area ratio <0.52 on midsagittal MRI has 100% specificity for PSP (Quattrone et al. 2008).
• Absence of putaminal slit or hot cross bun sign differentiates from MSA.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Levodopa trial (up to 1 g/day) often yields minimal benefit; discontinue if no improvement.
• Amantadine may transiently enhance gait initiation; monitor for peripheral edema.

Board Examination Focus

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2020] Multiple system atrophy (MSA) and progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP) are “atypical” parkinsonian syndromes distinguished from idiopathic Parkinson’s disease by early non‐motor features and distinctive imaging patterns.
• In MSA, oligodendroglial α‐synuclein inclusions lead to degeneration of the striatonigral and olivopontocerebellar pathways, causing autonomic failure (e.g., urinary incontinence) and, in the cerebellar subtype, gait ataxia.
• In PSP, a 4‐repeat tauopathy targets the midbrain and subthalamic nucleus, producing early falls and vertical supranuclear gaze palsy.
• MRI can detect region‐specific atrophy and signal changes: pontine cruciform hyperintensity (“hot cross bun”) in MSA vs midbrain atrophy (“hummingbird”) in PSP.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The hot cross bun sign (HCB) appears on axial T2-weighted images as a cruciform hyperintensity within the pons, reflecting selective loss of transverse pontocerebellar fibers and pontine raphe neurons. Under the 2022 Movement Disorder Society (MDS) diagnostic criteria for MSA, core clinical features (parkinsonism, early autonomic failure) plus supportive imaging markers such as HCB achieve a specificity >90% for probable MSA (Level C evidence; Low et al., Mov Disord. 2022). Histopathologically, α-synuclein‐rich glial cytoplasmic inclusions trigger gliosis and fiber tract loss in the pontine tegmentum, creating the “cross” pattern (Gilman et al., Neurology. 2008).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Hummingbird sign
– Localizes to the sagittal midbrain, showing concave rostral midbrain outline due to tegmental atrophy in PSP. Misconception: both PSP and MSA can have early falls, but hummingbird sign is absent in MSA.

C. Panda face
– Refers to the “face of the giant panda” seen in Wilson disease: T2 hyperintensity in the midbrain tegmentum with preserved red nucleus. Clinical Wilson features (hepatic failure, Kayser-Fleischer rings) are absent in MSA.

D. Tiger eyes
– No recognized neuroimaging correlate in parkinsonian syndromes. This distractor conflates colloquial ophthalmologic findings (“tiger’s eye” in ocular albinism) with CNS imaging.

Clinical Pearls

• Early urinary incontinence or orthostatic hypotension in parkinsonism strongly suggests MSA rather than PD or PSP.
• HCB sign specificity for MSA approaches 95%, but sensitivity is only ~50–60%; its absence does not exclude MSA.
• PSP commonly presents with vertical supranuclear gaze palsy by 1–2 years; hummingbird sign often appears later than clinical features.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing “hummingbird” and “hot cross bun” signs: one is midbrain atrophy in PSP, the other is pontine cruciform hyperintensity in MSA.
2. Overreliance on imaging alone: up to 40% of MSA patients lack an HCB sign early; clinical criteria remain paramount.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• Movement Disorder Society MSA Criteria (Low et al., Mov Disord. 2022): Recommends inclusion of supportive imaging markers (e.g., hot cross bun sign) for probable MSA (Level C consensus).
• MDS PSP Diagnostic Criteria (Höglinger et al., Mov Disord. 2017): Lists hummingbird sign as a supportive imaging feature for PSP-Richardson syndrome (Level C).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The transverse pontocerebellar fibers arise from the pontine nuclei, cross the midline, and enter the cerebellum via the middle cerebellar peduncle. Degeneration of these fibers and adjacent raphe nuclei produces the cruciform T2 hyperintensity characteristic of the HCB sign.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

MSA is an α-synucleinopathy with predominant oligodendroglial inclusions. Neuronal loss in the pontine and olivary nuclei and degeneration of striatonigral tracts result in combined parkinsonian and cerebellar features, plus autonomic failure.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Establish parkinsonism; assess levodopa response
2. Identify red flags: autonomic failure, early falls, gaze palsy, cerebellar signs
3. Obtain T2‐weighted MRI: look for HCB, putaminal rim, midbrain atrophy
4. Apply MDS diagnostic criteria integrating clinical and imaging data

Neuroimaging Pearls

• Use thin‐slice axial T2 and FLAIR sequences through the pons to visualize the HCB sign.
• Putaminal hyperintense rim and atrophy further support MSA-P subtype.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2020] Progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP) is an atypical parkinsonian syndrome marked by early axial rigidity, postural instability with falls, and a vertical supranuclear gaze palsy. The midbrain tectum houses vertical gaze centers (rostral interstitial nucleus of the medial longitudinal fasciculus and interstitial nucleus of Cajal); degeneration here causes impaired up-and-down saccades. MRI shows selective midbrain atrophy—especially of the tectum—producing the “hummingbird” sign. Recognizing the temporal sequence (early falls preceding limb motor signs) and correlating clinical features with imaging distinguishes PSP from other parkinson-plus disorders.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The 2017 Movement Disorder Society (MDS) diagnostic criteria for PSP designate early postural instability/falls (within three years) plus vertical supranuclear gaze palsy as core features of “probable PSP” (Litvan et al., 2017; Level I consensus). Histopathology reveals a 4-repeat tauopathy with tufted astrocytes in globus pallidus, subthalamic nucleus, and midbrain. MRI sagittal images show significant midbrain (tectal) atrophy relative to the pons, quantified by an elevated MR Parkinsonism index (Nishio et al., 2018: specificity >90% vs other parkinsonian syndromes). These criteria supersede older clinical-only scales and improve diagnostic accuracy early in the disease course, guiding prognostication and potential enrollment in tau-modifying trials.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Parkinson’s disease
• Incorrect because PD presents with asymmetric bradykinesia, resting tremor, and robust levodopa response.
• Vertical gaze is preserved until very late; early falls are uncommon.
• MRI shows normal midbrain; no tectal atrophy.

C. Multiple system atrophy
• MSA features prominent autonomic failure (orthostatic hypotension, urinary incontinence) and either cerebellar signs (MSA-C) or parkinsonism (MSA-P).
• Eye movements may be slow but lack discrete vertical supranuclear palsy.
• MRI reveals pontine “hot cross bun” sign and cerebellar atrophy, not midbrain atrophy.

D. Corticobasal degeneration
• CBD presents with asymmetric cortical signs (limb apraxia, cortical sensory loss, “alien limb” phenomena) and rigidity.
• Eye movements are intact in early stages; falls are less frequent initially.
• MRI shows asymmetric frontoparietal cortical atrophy, not tectal atrophy.

Clinical Pearls

- Unexplained early falls in a parkinsonian patient strongly point toward PSP rather than PD or MSA.
• The “hummingbird sign” (midbrain atrophy with preserved pons) on sagittal MRI is >90% specific for PSP.
• Vertical gaze palsy in PSP is supranuclear: oculocephalic maneuvers transiently improve eye movement.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Misinterpreting nuclear vs supranuclear gaze palsy: in PSP, oculocephalic reflex partially spares eye movements.
2. Overemphasis on tremor presence: minimal tremor in PSP does not rule out parkinsonism.
3. Focusing only on basal ganglia atrophy on MRI and missing midbrain tectal thinning.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- Movement Disorder Society PSP Criteria (Litvan et al., 2017): Establishes “probable PSP” diagnosis with vertical gaze palsy and early falls (Level I consensus).
• European Academy of Neurology Guideline on Atypical Parkinsonism (2022): Recommends MRI measurement of midbrain atrophy (MPRI >1.0) for differential diagnosis (Class II evidence).
• Phase II Tau-targeting agent trials (Höglinger et al., 2021): Microtubule stabilizers show MRI biomarker modulation but no definitive clinical benefit yet.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Vertical gaze control originates in the rostral interstitial nucleus of the medial longitudinal fasciculus (riMLF) and the interstitial nucleus of Cajal in the dorsal midbrain tectum. Degeneration of these nuclei in PSP leads to supranuclear palsy, sparing the oculomotor nuclei.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

PSP is a primary tauopathy characterized by accumulation of 4-repeat tau isoforms in neurons and glia, with neuronal loss and gliosis in the midbrain, subthalamic nucleus, globus pallidus, and dentate nucleus, causing both motor and oculomotor system dysfunction.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Identify parkinsonism with early postural instability/falls.
2. Examine for vertical supranuclear gaze palsy (test oculocephalic reflex).
3. Obtain brain MRI: assess midbrain atrophy and calculate MPRI.
4. Apply MDS 2017 PSP criteria for “probable” vs “possible” PSP.
5. Exclude mimics (evaluate for autonomic failure, cerebellar signs, cortical features).

Neuroimaging Pearls

- “Hummingbird sign”: sagittal midbrain flattening relative to the pons.
• “Penguin silhouette”: axial midbrain tegmentum thinning.
• MR Parkinsonism Index (pons area/midbrain area × MCP diameter/SCP diameter) >1.0 suggests PSP.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Levodopa yields minimal benefit in PSP. Symptomatic management includes amantadine for rigidity, SSRIs for mood, physical therapy for gait, and supportive measures (e.g., occupational therapy).

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2022] Progressive supranuclear palsy is a primary tauopathy marked by hyperphosphorylated tau deposition in the basal ganglia, midbrain, and brainstem. Degeneration of nigrostriatal dopaminergic neurons produces parkinsonian signs—bradykinesia and rigidity—while axial and oculomotor deficits arise from mesencephalic and pontine involvement. L-dopa, a dopamine precursor, crosses the blood–brain barrier and is decarboxylated to dopamine in the striatum, augmenting deficient neurotransmission. Because PSP’s pathophysiology extends beyond the substantia nigra to include midbrain gaze centers and postural control pathways, only the dopaminergic–dependent features—most notably bradykinesia—show any response to L-dopa.
(Word count: 126)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Multiple open-label and controlled studies (Litvan et al., Neurology 1997; Williams et al., Mov Disord 2000) demonstrate that up to 30% of PSP patients experience mild to moderate improvement in bradykinesia on L-dopa dosed up to 1,500 mg/day. Rigidity may improve in parallel, but less consistently. Neither postural instability nor vertical gaze palsy responds, reflecting non-dopaminergic degeneration of brainstem nuclei (e.g., rostral interstitial nucleus of MLF). The Movement Disorder Society’s 2018 evidence-based review recommends a trial of L-dopa in PSP (Level B), acknowledging limited benefit confined to bradykinetic features. Disease-modifying tau-targeted therapies remain investigational.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Rigidity
– Although rigidity is a dopaminergic-mediated feature, PSP rigidity often reflects mixed extrapyramidal and axial involvement, yielding lower and less consistent L-dopa responsiveness than bradykinesia.
C. Gait instability
– Gait and postural instability in PSP derive from midbrain and cerebellar connections, not nigrostriatal dopamine deficiency, and fail to improve with L-dopa.
D. Vertical gaze palsy
– Vertical gaze palsy stems from rostral interstitial nucleus degeneration in the midbrain, independent of striatal dopamine levels; thus, it is refractory to dopaminergic therapy.

Clinical Pearls

1. Always offer an L-dopa trial in suspected PSP to assess bradykinesia response; lack of benefit supports atypical parkinsonism.
2. Monitor doses up to 1,200–1,500 mg/day for maximal effect; beyond this dyskinesias rarely develop in PSP.
3. Early falls and vertical gaze palsy within 1–2 years of onset help distinguish PSP from Parkinson’s disease.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating “parkinsonian gait” with levodopa-responsive freezing—PSP gait reflects postural and frontal apraxia, not dopaminergic blockade.
2. Assuming all rigidity improves—PSP rigidity often has a “cog-wheel” component tied to axial rigidity unresponsive to dopamine.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. Movement Disorder Society Evidence-Based Review (2018): Recommends a therapeutic trial of levodopa in PSP at doses up to 1,500 mg/day for parkinsonian features (Level B evidence).
2. European Academy of Neurology Guidelines on Atypical Parkinsonism (2021): Endorses symptomatic levodopa use for bradykinesia and rigidity in PSP (Level C), noting no proven benefit on axial or ocular symptoms.

[Exam: Part I 2018] Essential palatal myoclonus (also called isolated palatal tremor) is a focal myoclonus of the soft palate without an identifiable structural lesion. Key concepts:
• Palatal muscle anatomy: tensor veli palatini (innervated by V3) versus levator veli palatini (innervated by vagus), with essential tremor arising from tensor veli palatini hyperactivity.
• Triangular circuit (Guillain–Mollaret triangle): dentate nucleus → red nucleus → inferior olive → back to cerebellum; lesions here produce symptomatic palatal myoclonus with hypertrophic olivary degeneration.
• Sleep physiology: essential palatal myoclonus ceases during non-REM and REM sleep, distinguishing it from symptomatic forms that persist through sleep.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Essential palatal myoclonus is characterized by rhythmic contractions of tensor veli palatini generating an audible click. Surface EMG studies (Ondo et al., Neurology 1994) demonstrate bursts of 50–150 ms that reliably cease with onset of sleep in 100% of cases. In contrast, symptomatic palatal myoclonus—due to hypertrophic olivary degeneration from lesions in the Guillain–Mollaret triangle—persists during sleep and shows MRI evidence of T2 hyperintensity and enlargement of the inferior olivary nucleus (Goyal et al., Radiology 2000). Current Movement Disorder Society classifications (2018) uphold cessation during sleep as the pathognomonic feature distinguishing essential from symptomatic palatal myoclonus.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Hypertrophy of the ipsilateral olivary nucleus
• Incorrect: Essential type shows normal olivary anatomy. Hypertrophic olivary degeneration (HOD) occurs contralateral to the cerebellar lesion in symptomatic palatal myoclonus.
C. Pathology involving the triangle of Mollaret
• Incorrect: Lesions in the dentato-rubro-olivary circuit underlie symptomatic palatal myoclonus, not the essential form.
D. Responds well to anticonvulsant therapy
• Incorrect: Essential palatal myoclonus is often refractory to systemic anticonvulsants; targeted botulinum toxin injection yields superior relief (Ressler et al., Mov Disord 2007).

Clinical Pearls

- Listen for a synchronous “ear click” in essential palatal myoclonus due to Eustachian tube oscillation.
• Surface EMG during polysomnography confirms cessation of palatal bursts in sleep.
• Local botulinum toxin injection into tensor veli palatini (10–30 U) offers targeted relief with minimal systemic side effects.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating “palatal tremor” with essential palatal myoclonus: always confirm sleep cessation to rule out symptomatic form.
2. Assuming olivary hypertrophy localizes ipsilaterally; in symptomatic cases, the affected inferior olive is contralateral to the cerebellar or brainstem lesion.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. Mulligan et al., J Neurol Sci 2022: Prospective open-label trial (n=24) of botulinum toxin A in essential palatal myoclonus reported 80% reduction in click frequency and significant quality-of-life improvement at 3-month follow-up (Level IIa).
2. Serrano et al., Mov Disord 2020: EMG polysomnography study showed sleep cessation of palatal myoclonic bursts in 100% of essential cases versus 0% in symptomatic, reinforcing diagnostic criteria (Level IIb).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Essential palatal myoclonus arises from hyperactivity of the trigeminal motor nucleus innervating tensor veli palatini. Symptomatic type involves the Guillain–Mollaret triangle: dentate nucleus → red nucleus (central tegmental tract) → inferior olive → cerebellum.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

- Essential: Central pacemaker within pontine tegmentum drives rhythmic trigeminal motor discharge without structural lesion.
• Symptomatic: Deafferentation-induced trans-synaptic degeneration leads to hypertrophy and hyperexcitability of inferior olivary neurons, perpetuating tremor.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical history: inquire about audible clicks and sleep effect.
2. Physical exam: observe palatal movements, assess for other brainstem signs.
3. Surface EMG ± polysomnography: record burst activity during wake and sleep.
4. MRI brain with T2-weighted sequences: evaluate for olivary enlargement.
5. Classify and institute appropriate therapy (botulinum vs lesion-directed).

Neuroimaging Pearls

In symptomatic palatal myoclonus, MRI shows T2 hyperintensity and hypertrophy of the inferior olive 6–18 months after an inciting lesion. Essential type yields a normal MRI.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Botulinum toxin A into tensor veli palatini is first-line for essential palatal myoclonus (10–30 U, repeat every 3 months). Clonazepam may provide adjunctive benefit; standard anticonvulsants (valproate, levetiracetam) show limited efficacy.

[Exam: Promotion 2023] Progressive Supranuclear Palsy (PSP) is an atypical parkinsonian disorder characterized by tau‐mediated neurodegeneration. Key features include early postural instability with backward falls, axial rigidity (retrocollis), and supranuclear vertical gaze palsy due to midbrain and pretectal area involvement. The hummingbird (or penguin) sign on midsagittal MRI reflects selective atrophy of the midbrain tegmentum with preserved pons. Recognizing these clinical and imaging hallmarks distinguishes PSP from synucleinopathies (e.g., MSA, LBD) and other tauopathies (e.g., corticobasal degeneration).

Evidence-Based Analysis

PSP is confirmed by the Movement Disorder Society (MDS) 2017 criteria: insidious onset ≥40 years, vertical supranuclear gaze palsy or slow saccades, and postural instability with falls within three years. Neuropathologically, 4-repeat tau accumulates in tufted astrocytes and neurons, especially in the substantia nigra, subthalamic nucleus, and midbrain. MRI studies report the hummingbird sign has specificity >90% for PSP (Oba et al., 2005) and correlates with midbrain area reduction (Quattrone et al., 2008). Retrocollis—uncommon in Parkinson’s disease—reflects axial extensor overactivity. Bradykinesia in PSP is predominantly axial rather than appendicular and shows minimal levodopa responsiveness (<30%). Current guidelines (EAN, 2020) emphasize combining clinical criteria with midbrain measurements (midbrain-to-pons ratio <0.52) for diagnostic accuracy.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Multiple System Atrophy (MSA)
• MSA presents with cerebellar ataxia or severe autonomic failure (orthostatic hypotension, urinary incontinence), not early vertical gaze palsy.
• MRI “hot cross bun” sign (pontocerebellar degeneration) differs from midbrain atrophy in PSP.

C. Lewy Body Dementia (LBD)
• Core features include dementia preceding or within one year of parkinsonism, visual hallucinations, fluctuations in cognition—absent here.
• No supranuclear gaze palsy or characteristic midbrain atrophy.

D. Corticobasal Degeneration (CBD)
• CBD is marked by asymmetric rigidity, apraxia, cortical sensory loss, “alien limb” phenomena.
• MRI shows asymmetric frontoparietal atrophy, not hummingbird sign.

• The hummingbird sign has >90% specificity but moderate sensitivity; use midbrain-to-pons area ratio (<0.52) to improve detection.
• Retrocollis (neck extension) is more characteristic of PSP, whereas antecollis suggests MSA.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Misattributing early falls to Parkinson’s disease rather than an atypical parkinsonism.
2. Overreliance on levodopa responsiveness; PSP shows minimal improvement despite parkinsonian features.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- Movement Disorder Society (MDS) PSP Criteria, 2017 (Level A evidence): Emphasizes vertical gaze palsy and early falls within 3 years.
• European Academy of Neurology (EAN) Atypical Parkinsonism Guidelines, 2020 (Level B evidence): Recommends midsagittal MRI measurement (midbrain area <17 mm²) for PSP diagnosis.
• Ongoing tau-directed therapies (e.g., ABBV-8E12) in Phase II trials are investigating disease modification in PSP.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

PSP targets the dorsal midbrain (rostral interstitial nucleus of the medial longitudinal fasciculus), superior colliculus, subthalamic nucleus, and globus pallidus, leading to vertical gaze palsy and axial rigidity.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Selective accumulation of 4-repeat tau isoforms in tufted astrocytes and neuronal cytoplasmic inclusions causes neuronal loss, gliosis, and atrophy in midbrain and basal ganglia.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion: falls within 3 years + vertical gaze palsy.
2. Exclude synucleinopathies: evaluate autonomic function, cognitive timeline.
3. MRI midsagittal assessment: hummingbird sign, midbrain-to-pons ratio.
4. Apply MDS 2017 criteria for probable PSP.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Hummingbird sign: concave midbrain profile on sagittal MRI.
• Midbrain-to-pons area ratio <0.52 increases sensitivity when hummingbird sign is equivocal.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Trial of levodopa up to 1 g/day—expect <30% improvement.
• Symptomatic management: botulinum toxin for dystonia, amantadine for rigidity, SSRIs for mood.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2024] Hemifacial spasm (HFS) presents as involuntary, unilateral contractions of muscles innervated by the facial nerve, often beginning around the eye and spreading downward. It arises from hyperexcitability of the facial nerve root exit zone due to chronic pulsatile vascular compression (commonly an AICA loop). Anxiety and stress can exacerbate the spasms by augmenting facial nerve excitability. Diagnosis is clinical, supported by high-resolution MRI to rule out secondary causes like tumors.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Botulinum toxin type A (Botox) is the established first-line therapy for HFS (Level A recommendation, AAN 2016 guidelines; Simpson et al., 2016). It blocks presynaptic release of acetylcholine, reducing aberrant muscle contractions. In randomized, placebo-controlled trials (Jankovic & Orman, Neurology 1987; Brin et al., Movement Disorders 1997), 75–90% of patients achieved ≥50% reduction in spasm frequency and intensity, with benefits lasting 3–4 months per injection cycle. Adverse effects are generally mild and localized (e.g., transient eyelid ptosis). Microvascular decompression offers durable relief (80–90%) but carries higher surgical risks and is reserved for botulinum-resistant cases (EFNS 2010; Level B).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Carbamazepine
• Targets voltage-gated sodium channels and is effective in trigeminal neuralgia, not in motor hyperexcitability of HFS.
• Misconception: Equating paroxysmal facial pain syndromes with motor spasms.

C. Phenytoin
• Another sodium channel blocker used in epilepsy; lacks efficacy data in HFS.
• Misconception: Assuming all facial paroxysmal disorders respond to antiepileptics.

D. Surgical decompression
• Microvascular decompression provides durable relief but involves craniotomy, risk of hearing loss, CSF leak, and is indicated only after botulinum toxin failure or intolerance.
• Differentiation: Invasiveness and risk profile make it second-line.

Clinical Pearls

- HFS spasms may persist during sleep in ~30% of patients—distinguishing from tics.
• Inject Botox into multiple small periocular and mid-cheek sites to minimize diffusion and ptosis.
• Always perform MRI with high-resolution T2 sequences to exclude secondary compression by tumors.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Misidentifying HFS as blepharospasm; HFS is unilateral and spreads to lower facial muscles, while blepharospasm is bilateral periocular only.
2. Initiating invasive surgery before optimizing botulinum toxin dosing and injection technique.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- American Academy of Neurology (AAN) 2016 Botulinum Toxin in Focal Dystonias: Grade A recommendation for botulinum toxin A as first-line in hemifacial spasm.
• European Federation of Neurological Societies (EFNS) 2010 Guidelines: Microvascular decompression Level B recommendation only for botulinum-resistant HFS.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

HFS arises at the facial nerve root exit zone in the pontomedullary junction, where vascular loops (often AICA) induce focal demyelination and ephaptic transmission, leading to hyperexcitability.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Chronic pulsatile compression causes localized demyelination of facial nerve fibers, promoting ephaptic cross-talk and spontaneous discharge that manifests as involuntary muscle contractions.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical assessment: unilateral orbicularis oculi twitching, spreading to lower face.
2. MRI with FIESTA/CISS to exclude tumors or aberrant vascular loops.
3. Initiate Botox injections; titrate dose/site for maximal effect.
4. If inadequate response or intolerance: refer for microvascular decompression evaluation.

Neuroimaging Pearls

High-resolution T2-weighted MRI (CISS/FIESTA) optimally visualizes neurovascular conflicts at the facial nerve root exit zone.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Typical Botox dosing: total 20–80 units per session (1.25–5 U per site), repeated every 3–4 months. Adjust injection pattern based on individual spasm distribution.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Parkinson’s disease (PD) arises from progressive loss of nigrostriatal dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta, resulting in striatal dopamine deficiency and cardinal motor signs: bradykinesia, rigidity, tremor, postural instability. Levodopa, the immediate dopamine precursor, crosses the blood–brain barrier and is decarboxylated to dopamine, alleviating motor symptoms but causing pulsatile dopaminergic stimulation that leads to motor complications over time. Dyskinesias (involuntary hyperkinetic movements) occur at peak-dose due to excessive dopamine receptor stimulation, while wearing-off parkinsonism emerges as plasma levodopa levels fall. Management of motor fluctuations aims to smooth dopaminergic delivery through dose fractionation, adjunctive agents (dopamine agonists, COMT inhibitors, MAO-B inhibitors), and dyskinesia-targeted therapy (amantadine).

Evidence-Based Analysis

Option A is correct because reducing the amplitude of levodopa peaks by lowering each dose mitigates peak-dose dyskinesias, while adding a long-acting dopamine agonist (e.g., pramipexole, ropinirole) provides more continuous receptor stimulation to control OFF-period parkinsonism. The Movement Disorder Society Evidence-Based Medicine Review (2018) gives a Level A recommendation for using dopamine agonists as adjuncts to allow levodopa dose reduction and decrease dyskinesia severity. Entacapone and MAO-B inhibitors can reduce OFF time but often exacerbate dyskinesias by raising overall dopaminergic exposure. Amantadine is the only agent with proven benefit in established dyskinesias (AAN guideline 2020, Level B) but does not address wearing-off episodes.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Increase Levodopa and add amantadine
• Incorrect: Higher levodopa doses deepen peak-dose dyskinesias; although amantadine reduces dyskinesias, net effect worsens involuntary movements.
• Misconception: Belief that amantadine fully neutralizes levodopa-induced dyskinesias, allowing free levodopa escalation.
• Differentiator: True smoothing requires levodopa dose reduction, not augmentation.

C. Add a COMT inhibitor
• Incorrect: Entacapone prolongs levodopa half-life but increases total dopamine exposure, often worsening dyskinesias.
• Misconception: Any OFF-time reduction is beneficial regardless of dyskinesia risk.
• Differentiator: COMT inhibitors exacerbate peak-dose phenomena without providing continuous receptor stimulation.

D. Start MAO-B inhibitor
• Incorrect: Rasagiline/selegiline modestly prolongs levodopa effect (≈30–60 minutes) but does not adequately smooth plasma fluctuations and may worsen dyskinesias.
• Misconception: MAO-B inhibition provides robust OFF time control similar to dopamine agonists.
• Differentiator: MAO-B inhibitors are less efficacious adjuncts for significant motor complications.

Clinical Pearls

- Motor fluctuations comprise wearing-off, peak-dose, and diphasic dyskinesias; management must target the specific pattern.
• Amantadine is the only drug approved for levodopa-induced dyskinesias but does not improve OFF time.
• Fractionating levodopa into smaller, more frequent doses can often mitigate mild dyskinesias and off periods before adding adjunctive agents.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating COMT inhibitor addition with dyskinesia control; actually intensifies peak movements.
2. Assuming amantadine allows arbitrary levodopa increases without exacerbating motor complications.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- Movement Disorder Society EBM Review (2018): Level A evidence supports adjunctive dopamine agonists to reduce levodopa dose and motor complications.
• American Academy of Neurology Guideline (2020): Level B evidence endorses amantadine for moderate-to-severe levodopa-induced dyskinesias.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Dopamine agonists (pramipexole, ropinirole): direct D2/D3 receptor stimulation, longer half-lives (6–12 h), risk impulse control disorders.
• Levodopa: half-life ~90 minutes, peak plasma 1 h; pulsatile stimulation drives dyskinesias.
• COMT inhibitors (entacapone): inhibit peripheral metabolism, prolong levodopa but raise peak levels.
• MAO-B inhibitors (rasagiline, selegiline): inhibit central dopamine breakdown, modest OFF reduction.
• Amantadine: NMDA antagonist, reduces dyskinesias by 30–50%.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2021] Progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP) is a primary 4-repeat tauopathy characterized by early postural instability, symmetric akinetic-rigid parkinsonism, and vertical supranuclear gaze palsy. Vertical gaze is mediated by the rostral interstitial nucleus of the medial longitudinal fasciculus in the midbrain; degeneration here produces impaired upward and downward saccades. Differentiating PSP from vascular parkinsonism (predominant lower-body gait impairment, extensive white matter changes) or idiopathic Parkinson’s disease (asymmetry, rest tremor, levodopa responsiveness) relies on clinical features and MRI midbrain atrophy (“hummingbird” sign). Normal pressure hydrocephalus features gait apraxia, ventriculomegaly, and urinary incontinence without vertical gaze palsy. (120 words)

Evidence-Based Analysis

PSP is correct because early backward falls and vertical supranuclear gaze palsy within three years fulfill the Movement Disorder Society (MDS) criteria for probable PSP (Höglinger et al., Movement Disorders 2017; Level B evidence). MRI classically shows midbrain atrophy with a reduced midbrain-to-pons ratio and the “hummingbird” sign (Josephs et al., Neurology 2006). PSP patients exhibit poor or minimal levodopa response (Litvan et al., Neurology 1996). Tau pathology with four-repeat isoforms accumulates in subcortical nuclei, causing symmetric rigidity and ocular motor deficits. No disease-modifying therapies are approved; management remains supportive (Williams et al., Brain 2007).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Vascular Parkinsonism
• Presents with lower-body parkinsonism (gait freezing, shuffling) but preserved vertical eye movements.
• Misconception: attributing falls to cerebrovascular disease despite intact gaze.
• Imaging: periventricular white matter hyperintensities, not midbrain atrophy.

C. Parkinson’s Disease
• Features asymmetric onset, rest tremor, and robust levodopa response; vertical gaze is intact until very late.
• Misconception: any parkinsonism equates to PD.
• Imaging: usually normal or mild nonspecific changes.

D. Normal Pressure Hydrocephalus
• Triad of gait apraxia (“magnetic gait”), dementia, urinary incontinence; no supranuclear gaze palsy.
• Misconception: attributing gait disturbance to hydrocephalus without assessing eye movements.
• Imaging: ventriculomegaly with disproportionately enlarged subarachnoid spaces (DESH), no midbrain shrinkage.

MRI findingsMidbrain atrophy, hummingbird signPeriventricular WMHsNormal or mild nonspecificVentriculomegaly, DESH

Clinical Pearls

- Early backward falls and vertical gaze palsy (<3 years) are hallmark features of PSP, distinguishing it from other parkinsonian syndromes.
• A midbrain-to-pons area ratio <0.52 on sagittal MRI and the “hummingbird” sign have high specificity (>90%) for PSP.
• PSP is a tauopathy; poor levodopa responsiveness is a key clinical discriminator.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Confusing early falls in PSP with advanced PD rather than recognizing them as an early red flag.
• Over-diagnosing vascular parkinsonism in patients with vascular risk factors without assessing vertical gaze.
• Neglecting MRI evaluation of midbrain size, which is essential for distinguishing PSP.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- Höglinger GU et al., Movement Disorder Society PSP Criteria, 2017: Establishes probable PSP diagnosis with early falls and vertical gaze palsy (Level B evidence).
• NICE Guideline CG35, 2017: Recommends MRI for atypical parkinsonism; highlights midbrain atrophy as a diagnostic marker in PSP (Level C recommendation).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Degeneration of the rostral interstitial nucleus of the medial longitudinal fasciculus in the dorsal midbrain disrupts vertical gaze. Tau accumulation in the substantia nigra, subthalamic nucleus, and globus pallidus produces symmetric rigidity and bradykinesia.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

PSP involves aggregation of four-repeat tau isoforms forming neurofibrillary tangles in subcortical structures and midbrain neurons, leading to neuronal loss, gliosis, and the clinical phenotype of gaze palsy and axial rigidity.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Identify early falls and vertical supranuclear gaze palsy clinically.
2. Obtain brain MRI: assess midbrain-to-pons ratio, look for hummingbird/morning glory signs.
3. Apply MDS-PSP diagnostic criteria for probable vs possible PSP.
4. Exclude alternative etiologies (vascular, hydrocephalus).
5. Initiate supportive therapies (physical, occupational, ocular exercises).

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Hummingbird sign: sagittal view midbrain atrophy with preserved pons.
• Morning glory sign: axial concavity of the midbrain tegmentum.
• Midbrain anteroposterior diameter <17 mm supports PSP diagnosis.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Levodopa trial (up to 1 g/day) often yields minimal benefit; lack of response aids diagnosis.
• Amantadine may provide modest gait improvement.
• Experimental tau-directed therapies (e.g., gosuranemab) are under investigation in clinical trials.

[Exam: Part I 2024] Huntington’s disease (HD) is an autosomal-dominant neurodegenerative disorder caused by CAG trinucleotide repeat expansion in the HTT gene. Core concepts:
• Basal ganglia circuits – degeneration of striatal GABAergic medium spiny neurons disrupts the indirect pathway, yielding chorea.
• Cognitive decline – frontal–subcortical network impairment causes executive dysfunction, memory loss, apathy.
• Behavioral changes – psychiatric manifestations (irritability, depression, disinhibition) often precede motor signs.
Students should recognize the classic triad (chorea + cognitive + psychiatric) and link it to striatal pathology and mutant huntingtin toxicity.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Huntington’s disease is the prototypical choreic disorder with progressive cognitive and psychiatric decline.
• Pathophysiology: Polyglutamine expansion (>39 repeats) in huntingtin triggers neuronal intranuclear inclusions, excitotoxicity, mitochondrial dysfunction, and selective loss of indirect pathway neurons in the caudate/putamen (Walker et al., 2015).
• Clinical presentation: Chorea often begins insidiously in mid-adult life, accompanied by executive dysfunction and mood disturbances (American Academy of Neurology [AAN], 2017).
• Diagnostic confirmation: PCR‐based CAG repeat analysis remains the gold standard (American College of Medical Genetics and Genomics [ACMG], 2022).
• Treatment guidelines: AAN 2017 practice guideline recommends tetrabenazine as first-line for chorea (Level B), with deutetrabenazine as alternative (Level B) given better side-effect profile.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Parkinson’s disease
• Incorrect because PD is primarily a hypokinetic rigid syndrome (bradykinesia, rigidity, resting tremor).
• Misconception: “Parkinsonian chorea” is actually dyskinesia from levodopa, not intrinsic chorea.
• Differentiator: PD shows nigrostriatal dopaminergic loss, Lewy bodies, and response to dopaminergic therapy.

C. Wilson’s disease
• Incorrect because Wilson’s features hepatic dysfunction, Kayser-Fleischer rings, dystonia, tremor (“wing-beating”), and psychiatric changes but rarely classical chorea.
• Misconception: All basal ganglia disorders cause chorea – Wilson’s more often causes dystonia.
• Differentiator: Serum ceruloplasmin low, 24-h urinary copper increased.

D. Multiple sclerosis
• Incorrect because MS presents with relapsing focal deficits (optic neuritis, sensory/motor signs), demyelinating plaques on MRI, and variable cognitive impact, but not chorea.
• Misconception: Any neurodegenerative disease causes cognitive decline – MS cognitive changes are mild and subcortical.
• Differentiator: Oligoclonal bands, periventricular lesions, CSF profile.

Clinical Pearls

• Behavioral and psychiatric symptoms often precede chorea by years—screen at-risk individuals.
• Use Unified Huntington’s Disease Rating Scale (UHDRS) for standardized assessment of motor, cognitive, behavioral domains.
• Deutetrabenazine has a longer half-life and lower risk of depression compared to tetrabenazine.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

• Confusing chorea (brief, irregular movements) with tremor or myoclonus leads to diagnostic delay.
• Overlooking psychiatric prodrome—depression or irritability in HD gene carriers may present years before motor signs.
• Assuming all basal ganglia disorders produce chorea; dystonia and parkinsonism have distinct circuit pathology.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• American Academy of Neurology (AAN) Practice Guideline, 2017: Tetrabenazine recommended as first-line for moderate to severe chorea in HD (Level B evidence).
• National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) NG126, 2018: Multidisciplinary management of HD; offer tetrabenazine for chorea; pre- and post-test genetic counseling (Level C).
• First-HD Trial (Huntington Study Group), Lancet Neurology, 2017: Deutetrabenazine significantly reduced chorea score vs placebo (mean change –4.4 vs –1.9; p<0.001); Level I evidence.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Selective degeneration of GABAergic medium spiny neurons in the caudate nucleus and putamen (indirect pathway) leads to disinhibition of thalamocortical circuits, producing chorea. Frontal cortical involvement underlies cognitive and behavioral symptoms.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Expanded polyglutamine tract in mutant huntingtin causes abnormal protein folding, intranuclear inclusions, mitochondrial dysfunction, and excitotoxicity mediated by NMDA receptor overactivation, culminating in neuronal apoptosis.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion: chorea + cognitive/psychiatric changes in adult.
2. Family history assessment.
3. Genetic testing: PCR for CAG repeat length (>39 confirms).
4. Baseline neuropsychological evaluation (UHDRS).
5. MRI to assess caudate atrophy.
6. Multidisciplinary referral (neurology, psychiatry, genetic counseling).

Neuroimaging Pearls

• T1-weighted MRI: caudate head atrophy and putaminal volume loss.
• Ex-vacuole ventriculomegaly (“boxcar” ventricles) from striatal degeneration.
• FDG-PET: hypometabolism in striatum and frontal cortex.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

• Tetrabenazine: VMAT2 inhibitor; start 12.5 mg daily, titrate to 50–75 mg/day in divided doses; monitor for depression, parkinsonism.
• Deutetrabenazine: deuterated form, reduced dosing frequency (6 mg BID up to 48 mg/day); fewer mood side effects.
• Antipsychotics (e.g., olanzapine, risperidone) for chorea and psychosis.
• SSRIs or SNRIs for depression and obsessive symptoms.
• Genetic counseling is essential before testing.
