[Exam: Part 2 2020] Orthostatic tremor (OT) is a rare, high-frequency (13–18 Hz) central tremor of the legs manifesting as subjective unsteadiness on standing. Unlike essential tremor or parkinsonian tremor, OT arises from a central oscillator—likely within brainstem–spinal circuits—driving synchronous muscle discharges. First-line therapy potentiates GABA_A receptors with clonazepam. When benzodiazepines are insufficient or poorly tolerated, modulation of presynaptic calcium channels and enhancement of GABAergic tone with gabapentin can suppress the pathological oscillator. Recognizing OT’s unique neurophysiology and pharmacology is essential for appropriate escalation of therapy.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Gabapentin, a GABA analogue that binds the α2δ subunit of voltage-gated calcium channels, reduces excitatory neurotransmission in central oscillatory networks. In open-label series (Trapella et al., 2002), 60% of clonazepam-refractory patients experienced >30% improvement in standing tolerance with gabapentin (900–2400 mg/day). A retrospective review (Sperling et al., 2006) corroborated benefit in 40–50% of such cases. The 2020 Movement Disorder Society consensus (Level C evidence) endorses gabapentin as second-line after clonazepam failure. By contrast, levodopa targets dopaminergic deficits not implicated in OT; propranolol and primidone act peripherally or via barbiturate mechanisms effective in essential tremor but lack robust data in OT.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Levodopa
• Ineffective: OT is not dopaminergic.
• Misconception: Equating resting PD tremor with weight-bearing tremor.
• Differentiator: OT lacks basal ganglia dopamine deficiency.

B. Propranolol
• Ineffective: Beta-blockade reduces peripheral tremor amplitude but not central high-frequency OT.
• Misconception: All action tremors respond to β-blockers.
• Differentiator: OT’s pathogenesis is central oscillator–driven, not adrenergic.

D. Primidone
• Limited evidence: Primidone benefits essential tremor via barbiturate metabolites but has only anecdotal OT reports and high sedation risk.
• Misconception: Classification of all postural tremors under essential tremor treatments.
• Differentiator: Primidone lacks controlled studies in OT and carries more adverse effects than gabapentin.

Clinical Pearls

• Confirm OT with surface EMG showing 13–18 Hz rhythmic bursts in leg muscles on standing.
• Initiate clonazepam (0.5–2 mg/day) first; if inadequate or poorly tolerated, titrate gabapentin to 900–2400 mg/day.
• Differentiate OT from orthostatic hypotension by the absence of blood pressure drops.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

• Mislabeling OT as essential tremor and defaulting to propranolol or primidone without EMG confirmation.
• Overlooking central high-frequency tremor and treating unsteadiness as vestibular or cerebellar pathology.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• Movement Disorder Society Consensus Statement 2020: Recommends benzodiazepines first-line; gabapentin second-line in refractory OT (Level C evidence).
• European Federation of Neurological Societies (EFNS) Guidelines 2018: Classifies gabapentin as a recommended second-line agent based on cohort studies (Level B evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

OT originates from a central oscillator within brainstem reticular formation projecting to spinal motor neurons of weight-bearing muscles. Synchronous discharge travels via ventral roots to lower-limb musculature.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

A malfunctioning central oscillator generates rapid rhythmic discharges (13–18 Hz) in leg muscles upon standing. Excess excitatory neurotransmission via voltage-gated calcium channels sustains tremor amplitude.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion: subjective unsteadiness on standing without visible tremor.
2. Surface EMG: confirm 13–18 Hz rhythmic bursts on weight-bearing.
3. Exclude other tremor etiologies and orthostatic hypotension.
4. Initiate clonazepam; if refractory, escalate to gabapentin.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

• Clonazepam: GABA_A potentiator, start 0.25 mg BID, max 4 mg/day.
• Gabapentin: begin 300 mg TID, titrate by 300 mg/week to 900–2400 mg/day. Monitor for sedation.

[Exam: Promotion 2022] Corticobasal degeneration (CBD) is an atypical parkinsonian disorder characterized by asymmetric motor dysfunction and cortical signs. Core concepts include:
• Basal ganglia circuitry: degeneration of the supplementary motor area and striatal-thalamocortical loops produces bradykinesia, rigidity, and dystonia.
• Cortical involvement: frontoparietal atrophy leads to apraxia, cortical sensory loss, and myoclonus.
• Clinical heterogeneity: CBD often presents unilaterally in the upper limb with “alien limb” phenomena—the patient may use proximal muscles (e.g., head turning) to compensate for limb dyspraxia.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Corticobasal degeneration is defined by Armstrong et al.’s 2013 consensus criteria as a 4-repeat tauopathy with hallmark asymmetric parkinsonism plus cortical dysfunction. This patient’s left arm dystonia, bradykinesia, and stimulus-sensitive myoclonus, in combination with compensatory head movements (“alien limb–type” behavior), fulfill the clinical research criteria for probable CBD.
Neuroimaging often reveals asymmetric frontoparietal cortical atrophy on MRI and hypometabolism on FDG-PET. Pathologically, CBD demonstrates neuronal and glial tau inclusions predominantly in the supplementary motor area, premotor cortex, and basal ganglia.
Current Movement Disorder Society evidence-based reviews (MDS EBM) underline that levodopa response in CBD is limited and myoclonus may respond to benzodiazepines or levetiracetam. No disease-modifying therapy exists; management focuses on symptomatic relief and physiotherapy.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Frontotemporal dementia (FTD)
FTD presents with early behavioral disinhibition, executive dysfunction, or language variant aphasia, not asymmetric parkinsonism with dystonia/myoclonus. Misconception: FTD can overlap motor neuron disease but typically lacks isolated limb dystonia and myoclonus.

B. Alzheimer's disease (AD)
AD’s hallmark is progressive episodic memory impairment, later visuospatial deficits, and hippocampal atrophy. Parkinsonian features are rare and symmetric; dystonia/myoclonus is not a presenting feature.

C. Dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB)
DLB includes visual hallucinations, cognitive fluctuations, REM sleep behavior disorder, and symmetric parkinsonism. Myoclonus can occur but dystonia is unusual and cortical sensory signs are not prominent.

Clinical Pearls

- Unilateral arm dystonia with myoclonus and “alien limb” behavior is virtually pathognomonic for CBD.
• MRI showing asymmetric frontoparietal atrophy supports CBD over other parkinsonian syndromes.
• Response to levodopa is minimal; manage myoclonus with clonazepam or levetiracetam.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Confusing alien-limb signs in CBD with chorea in Huntington’s disease—alien-limb is cortical dyspraxia, not choreiform hyperkinesia.
• Attributing early dystonia to Parkinson’s disease (PD)—PD dystonia is typically foot or cervical and responds to levodopa, whereas CBD dystonia is limb-predominant and levodopa-unresponsive.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- Armstrong MJ et al. (Movement Disorders, 2013): Consensus criteria for corticobasal syndrome emphasize asymmetric parkinsonism + cortical signs; Level C evidence.
• Movement Disorder Society EBM Review (2018): Recommends benzodiazepines or levetiracetam for CBD-associated myoclonus; Level B evidence.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

CBD primarily affects the supplementary motor area, premotor cortex, and frontoparietal cortices, with secondary degeneration in the striatum and globus pallidus, disrupting both cortical motor planning and basal ganglia outflow.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Selective accumulation of 4R tau isoforms in neurons and astrocytes leads to neuronal loss, gliosis, and white matter tract degeneration, resulting in combined cortical (apraxia, sensory loss) and subcortical (parkinsonism, dystonia, myoclonus) deficits.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical history: unilateral limb onset, dystonia, myoclonus.
2. Neurological exam: identify cortical signs (apraxia, cortical sensory deficits, alien-limb phenomena).
3. MRI brain: assess for asymmetric frontoparietal atrophy.
4. Functional imaging (FDG-PET): confirm regional hypometabolism.
5. Exclude mimics: metabolic, vascular, or inflammatory etiologies.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- MRI: “knife-edge” atrophy of parietal cortex contralateral to affected limb.
• FDG-PET: asymmetric hypometabolism in frontoparietal regions.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Levodopa: minimal benefit; trial may be attempted to exclude PD.
• Myoclonus: clonazepam 0.5–1 mg at bedtime or levetiracetam 500 mg BID.
• Dystonia: botulinum toxin injections for focal relief; physical and occupational therapy integrally.

[Exam: Promotion 2018] Corticobasal degeneration (CBD) is an asymmetric 4-repeat tauopathy targeting frontoparietal cortex and basal ganglia circuits. Key features include:
• Cortical motor and sensory dysfunction: limb apraxia, cortical sensory loss (astereognosis, graphesthesia).
• Extrapyramidal features: rigid dystonia, myoclonus, “alien limb” phenomenon.
• Progressive asymmetric presentation differentiates it from symmetric parkinsonian disorders.
Understanding neurodegeneration in sensorimotor integration and basal ganglia–thalamocortical loops is essential to recognize CBD’s distinctive clinical phenotype.

(Word count: 98)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Corticobasal degeneration is defined by asymmetric frontoparietal atrophy with neuronal tau inclusions causing both cortical and basal ganglia dysfunction. The 2013 Movement Disorder Society (MDS) CBD diagnostic criteria (Armstrong et al., 2013; Level II evidence) emphasize:
• Asymmetric limb rigidity or dystonia.
• Cortical signs: myoclonus, apraxia, cortical sensory loss.
• Progressive course without early falls or gaze palsy.
In clinical cohorts (Litvan et al., 2016), >90% of CBD patients present with unilateral rigidity plus cortical deficits. MRI often shows contralateral frontoparietal atrophy; FDG-PET reveals hypometabolism in these regions. No other parkinsonian syndrome produces this precise combination of myoclonus and cortical sensory loss in a progressive, asymmetric pattern.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Basal ganglia stroke
— Acute onset with stepwise or static deficits, not insidious progression.
— Stroke rarely produces focal cortical sensory loss with myoclonus in isolation; imaging differentiates.

C. Progressive Supranuclear Palsy (PSP)
— Characterized by early postural instability/falls and vertical gaze palsy.
— PSP presents symmetrically, lacks true cortical sensory loss or limb apraxia.

D. Multiple System Atrophy (MSA)
— Features autonomic failure (orthostasis, urinary incontinence) plus parkinsonism or cerebellar signs.
— No prominent cortical signs (myoclonus/apraxia) and typically symmetric involvement.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Misdiagnosing PSP as CBD due to rigidity: look for early falls and vertical gaze palsy in PSP.
2. Attributing focal myoclonus to stroke without considering progressive nature and cortical sensory signs.

– Recommendation: Diagnose “probable CBD” when asymmetric rigidity plus ≥2 cortical signs present. (Level II)
2. MDS-PSP Diagnostic Criteria Update (Höglinger et al., 2017):
– Emphasizes early falls and ocular signs to differentiate from CBD. (Level III)

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Degeneration involves:
• Primary sensorimotor cortex → limb apraxia, cortical sensory loss.
• Supplementary motor area and basal ganglia loops → rigidity, myoclonus.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

CBD is a 4-repeat tauopathy. Abnormal tau accumulates in neurons and glia of frontoparietal cortex and basal ganglia, leading to neuronal loss, gliosis, and progressive asymmetric dysfunction.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical evaluation: asymmetric rigidity + cortical signs.
2. MRI brain: assess frontoparietal atrophy.
3. Rule out vascular, inflammatory, metabolic causes.
4. FDG-PET or tau PET (research) for metabolic signature.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Asymmetric frontoparietal cortical atrophy on MRI.
• FDG-PET: hypometabolism in contralateral sensorimotor cortex.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Symptomatic: trial of levodopa (often poor response).
• Myoclonus: clonazepam or valproate.
• Dystonia: botulinum toxin injections; supportive therapy.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2023] Parkinson’s disease arises from degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta, causing striatal dopamine deficiency and disrupted balance between the direct (D1-mediated) and indirect (D2-mediated) basal ganglia pathways. Levodopa remains the most effective therapy but has a short plasma half-life (~1.5–2 hours) and, in advanced disease, diminished storage capacity in presynaptic terminals leads to pulsatile dopaminergic stimulation. This underlies motor fluctuations: “wearing-off” when levodopa levels fall below the therapeutic threshold and peak-dose dyskinesias when levels exceed it. Optimizing motor control hinges on smoothing these peaks and troughs via fractionated dosing or adjunct enzyme inhibitors before considering invasive therapies.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Decreasing the individual levodopa dose while increasing dosing frequency produces a more continuous dopaminergic stimulation, reducing both OFF time and peak-dose dyskinesias. Stacy et al. (Neurology 2005;65:1498–1503) demonstrated that fractionated levodopa regimens decreased OFF time by 30% and peak dyskinesias by 40% versus standard four-hour intervals. The Movement Disorder Society evidence-based review (Oertel et al., 2018) gives a Level A recommendation for dose fractionation in motor fluctuations. Levodopa’s short half-life and loss of presynaptic storage in advanced PD narrow the therapeutic window; smaller, more frequent doses maintain plasma levels within this window. If fractionation is insufficient, adding a COMT inhibitor (e.g., entacapone) or MAO-B inhibitor (e.g., rasagiline) can further extend levodopa’s effect. Deep brain stimulation (DBS) is reserved for patients with refractory fluctuations despite optimized medical therapy (typically ≥5 years of disease). Increasing total levodopa dosage worsens dyskinesias, and switching monotherapy to another class without first optimizing levodopa scheduling is less effective.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Consider referral for subthalamic nucleus DBS
– Reserved for motor complications refractory to optimized pharmacotherapy after ≥5 years of disease.
– Misconception: surgical therapy precedes full medical optimization.

C. Increase the dose of levodopa
– Raises peak plasma levels, exacerbating dyskinesias, and still leads to wearing-off as half-life remains unchanged.
– Misconception: more drug always ameliorates OFF periods.

D. Switch to a different medication
– Changing to a dopamine agonist or other class may address wearing-off but often worsens dyskinesias or causes impulse control disorders; not first-line without adjusting levodopa regimen.

Clinical Pearls

1. Early motor fluctuations respond best to levodopa dose fractionation before adding adjuncts.
2. Peak-dose dyskinesias signal supratherapeutic dopamine levels—manage by reducing individual doses.
3. DBS is highly effective for refractory fluctuations but only after thorough pharmacologic optimization.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Prescribing higher levodopa doses to treat wearing-off without addressing dyskinesias worsens motor complications.
2. Referring patients for DBS before exhausting medical adjustments leads to suboptimal outcomes.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. Movement Disorder Society (Oertel et al., 2018): Level A evidence for fractionated levodopa dosing in motor fluctuations.
2. European Parkinson’s Disease Association Consensus (2021): Level B recommendation to add COMT inhibitors if dose fractionation is inadequate.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Degeneration of nigrostriatal dopaminergic neurons reduces dopamine in the dorsal striatum, disrupting direct (facilitatory) and indirect (inhibitory) basal ganglia pathways and leading to bradykinesia and rigidity.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Advanced PD causes loss of presynaptic dopamine storage; levodopa pharmacokinetics directly dictate motor response (“on/off” phenomena). Pulsatile dopamine receptor stimulation induces synaptic plasticity changes underlying dyskinesias.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Levodopa/carbidopa dosing must balance achieving therapeutic troughs without supratherapeutic peaks. Fractionation (e.g., every 2–3 hours) flattens plasma curves; adjunct COMT or MAO-B inhibitors further prolong effect.

This question appeared in Promotion 2023 exam. Management of levodopa-induced motor fluctuations is tested frequently on neurology promotion and board exams, often in vignette form requiring understanding of pharmacokinetics and therapeutic window strategies.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2021] Parkinson’s disease arises from degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta, leading to dopamine deficiency in the dorsal striatum. Cardinal motor signs—bradykinesia, rigidity, resting tremor—are due to imbalance in direct (facilitatory) and indirect (inhibitory) basal ganglia pathways. Diagnosis is clinical; imaging (DaT-SPECT or PET) is reserved for unclear cases. Symptomatic therapy aims to restore dopaminergic tone, with levodopa/​carbidopa providing the most robust motor improvement. Carbidopa inhibits peripheral decarboxylation of levodopa, increasing CNS availability and reducing nausea/orthostatic hypotension.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Levodopa/​carbidopa is the gold standard for moderate-to-severe Parkinson’s. The PD MED trial (BMJ 2014; n = 1,613) showed early levodopa led to superior long-term quality-of-life (p < 0.01) versus dopamine agonist or MAO-B inhibitor monotherapy. Movement Disorder Society guidelines (2018) assign a Level A recommendation to levodopa for symptomatic control in patients with motor impairment affecting daily activities. Carbidopa (25 mg per dose) prevents peripheral conversion, minimizing GI side effects (Katzenschlager et al., Ann Neurol 2002). Entacapone, a COMT inhibitor, is indicated only after end-of-dose “wearing-off” emerges. Routine PET or DaTscan is not required when clinical criteria are met. Dopamine agonists (e.g., pramipexole) are less potent, carry higher impulse control disorder risk (Level B), and are reserved for mild symptoms in younger patients aiming to delay dyskinesias.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Levodopa/Carbidopa/Entacapone
• Why incorrect: COMT inhibitors like entacapone are added to manage motor fluctuations (wearing-off), not at initial diagnosis.
• Misconception: Belief that upfront COMT inhibition improves long-term motor control.
• Differentiator: Entacapone’s benefit emerges only after levodopa plasma peaks become erratic.

C. PET Scan
• Why incorrect: Metabolic imaging (e.g., FDOPA PET) or DaT-SPECT confirms nigrostriatal loss but is unnecessary in a patient with classic signs.
• Misconception: Assuming imaging is mandatory for diagnosis.
• Differentiator: Clinical diagnostic criteria (UK Brain Bank) suffice; imaging is second-line.

D. Dopamine agonists
• Why incorrect: Though agonists can delay levodopa-induced dyskinesias in patients <60 with mild symptoms, they provide inferior symptom control and higher rates of impulse control disorders.
• Misconception: Younger age universally mandates agonist monotherapy.
• Differentiator: Levodopa’s superior efficacy outweighs dyskinesia risk when daily function is impaired.

Clinical Pearls

- Always pair levodopa with ≥25 mg carbidopa to reduce peripheral side effects.
• Initiate at 100 mg/25 mg TID and titrate weekly by 100 mg levodopa increments to minimize dyskinesias.
• Monitor for wear-off; add entacapone (200 mg) only when end-of-dose motor fluctuations develop.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Ordering DaT-SPECT or PET in classic presentations, which rarely alters management.
2. Starting COMT inhibitors de novo, increasing pill burden without benefit.
3. Preferring dopamine agonists in younger patients regardless of symptom severity.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- Movement Disorder Society (MDS) Evidence-based Review, 2018: Level A recommendation for levodopa/carbidopa in moderate-to-severe PD; dopamine agonists Level B for delaying dyskinesias in mild PD.
• NICE Guideline CG35, 2017: Recommends levodopa for patients ≥65 years; consider dopamine agonists or MAO-B inhibitors in <65 years with mild symptoms.
• PD MED Trial, BMJ 2014: Early levodopa was superior to dopamine agonist/MAO-B inhibitor monotherapy in long-term mobility and quality of life.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Degeneration of nigrostriatal dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta reduces dopamine in the caudate and putamen, disrupting direct (D1-mediated) and indirect (D2-mediated) basal ganglia pathways and leading to bradykinesia and rigidity.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Misfolded α-synuclein forms Lewy bodies, triggering neuronal apoptosis in the SNpc; symptom onset occurs after 60–80% neuronal loss, causing striatal dopamine depletion and impaired thalamocortical activation.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical assessment: Confirm bradykinesia + rigidity or rest tremor.
2. Exclude “red flags” (e.g., rapid progression, early autonomic failure).
3. Optional imaging (DaT-SPECT) if diagnosis remains uncertain.
4. Initiate symptomatic therapy based on severity, age, and lifestyle.

Neuroimaging Pearls

DaT-SPECT reveals reduced striatal dopamine transporter binding (especially posterior putamen) in PD; normal in essential tremor, aiding differentiation.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Levodopa/carbidopa mechanism: Levodopa crosses BBB → decarboxylated to dopamine centrally; carbidopa inhibits peripheral DOPA decarboxylase. Start 100 mg/25 mg TID, titrate up; monitor for motor fluctuations and dyskinesias, adding entacapone or MAO-B inhibitors as needed.

[Exam: Part 2 2023] Sensory tricks (geste antagoniste) are voluntary maneuvers or touches that transiently alleviate dystonic muscle contractions. Key points:
• Dystonia arises from abnormal basal ganglia–thalamo–cortical and cerebellar circuit dysfunction, leading to impaired surround inhibition.
• In cervical dystonia (spasmodic torticollis), gentle stimulation of the chin or face provides proprioceptive input that transiently restores inhibitory control over overactive neck muscles.
• Recognition of sensory tricks differentiates true dystonic posturing from mimics (e.g., cervical spondylosis) and guides targeted management.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The correct answer is A. Torticollis (cervical dystonia) because sensory tricks are most prevalent in this form. In landmark series, 68–80% of cervical dystonia patients report relief with tactile stimuli to the face or neck (Capelle et al., Mov Disord 2008; Jankovic J, 1988). The 2016 American Academy of Neurology guideline on botulinum toxin for cervical dystonia (Level A evidence) cites geste antagoniste as a supportive diagnostic feature. Neurophysiological studies (Hallett, Brain 2011) demonstrate that facial touch modulates thalamic somatosensory gating, normalizing aberrant basal ganglia output and reducing sternocleidomastoid overactivity. No other focal dystonia consistently exhibits this face-touch phenomenon.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Writer’s cramp
• Involves focal hand muscles; sensory feedback from the face does not modulate hand motor programs.
• Misconception: all dystonias respond to sensory tricks.
• Differentiator: improvement only with altered hand posture or writing-specific aids.

C. Blepharospasm
• Affects orbicularis oculi; periocular rubbing may transiently help but classic face touch (chin/cheek) does not alleviate eyelid spasms.
• Misconception: any facial contact eases all dystonias.
• Differentiator: uses “sensory trick” above the eyebrow, not jaw/face.

D. Dystonic tremor
• Tremor superimposed on dystonic posturing; sensory tricks rarely reduce tremor amplitude.
• Misconception: tremor in dystonia is modulated like pure dystonic contractions.
• Differentiator: tremor frequency persists despite facial touch.

Clinical Pearls

- Always inquire about maneuvers or touches that relieve dystonia; this guides diagnosis.
• Presence of a sensory trick correlates with better response to botulinum toxin injection in cervical dystonia.
• Differentiating dystonia from musculoskeletal neck pain hinges on identifying involuntary posturing and geste antagoniste.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Equating any tactile relief in neck pain with a true sensory trick of dystonia.
• Assuming sensory tricks are universal across all dystonias; they are most robust in cervical dystonia.
• Overreliance on imaging—in isolated focal dystonia without red flags, MRI is seldom diagnostic.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. American Academy of Neurology Practice Guideline (Jankovic et al., 2016)
• Recommends botulinum toxin A as first-line for cervical dystonia (Level A).
• Recognizes geste antagoniste as a supportive diagnostic criterion (Expert opinion).
2. International Parkinson and Movement Disorder Society Consensus (MDS, 2018)
• Classifies sensory tricks as “definite” clinical features for idiopathic focal dystonia.
• Level: Expert consensus, based on multicenter observational cohorts.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

- Basal ganglia: dysfunction in the putamen and globus pallidus interna leads to loss of inhibitory output.
• Thalamus: ventral posterolateral nucleus integrates proprioceptive input; facial touch modulates this relay.
• Sensorimotor cortex: altered plasticity amplifies abnormal muscle synergies in dystonia.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

- Impaired GABAergic inhibition within the basal ganglia–thalamocortical loop
• Abnormal sensorimotor integration with defective surround inhibition
• Sensory trick restores transient inhibitory interneuron activity via augmented afferent feedback

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. History: onset, task specificity, presence of sensory tricks
2. Examination: demonstrate dystonic posturing and attempt light touch to face/neck
3. Exclude secondary causes (red flags: acute onset, myelopathy)
4. Electromyography only if diagnosis remains unclear

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2023 exam. Sensory tricks in focal dystonias—especially cervical dystonia—are high-yield. Examinees should recall that chin or facial touch transiently relieves torticollis, a classic geste antagoniste.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2020] Paroxysmal dyskinesias are episodic hyperkinetic movement disorders mediated by basal ganglia circuit dysfunction.
1. “Kinesigenic” indicates attacks triggered by sudden voluntary movement (e.g., turning, startle) lasting seconds.
2. “Exercise-induced” dyskinesia arises after prolonged exertion (minutes), with attacks usually lasting longer.
3. Genetic forms include PRRT2 mutations (PKD) and TOR1A (DYT1), but DYT1 causes persistent dystonia, not paroxysmal.
4. Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy presents with early-morning myoclonic jerks and generalized spike-wave discharges, not movement-triggered dystonia.
Recognition of precise triggers, duration, and phenomenology is key for accurate classification.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Paroxysmal kinesigenic dyskinesia (PKD) is characterized by brief (seconds–minutes) dystonic or choreoathetoid episodes precipitated by sudden movement or startle. PRRT2 gene mutations underlie ~60% of familial cases, disrupting presynaptic vesicle release and neuronal excitability. First-line therapy with low-dose carbamazepine (100–200 mg/d) yields >90% response (Rock et al., 2014; MDS Evidence-Based Guideline 2017, Level A). Attacks resolve by adolescence in many. Video-EEG studies are normal during episodes, distinguishing PKD from epileptic myoclonus. Family history of migraine is common in PRRT2 mutation carriers, reflecting shared neuronal hyperexcitability pathways (Zhang et al., 2015).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Paroxysmal exercise-induced dyskinesia
• Triggered by prolonged exertion (e.g., >5 min running), not sudden turns.
• Attacks onset latency of minutes and last longer (5–30 min).
• Responds less robustly to carbamazepine (MDS Guideline 2017, Level C).

C. DYT1
• TOR1A mutation causes early-onset generalized dystonia, persistent rather than episodic.
• No clear movement trigger, often begins in leg/arm and generalizes.

D. Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy
• Presents with bilateral myoclonic jerks, generalized tonic-clonic seizures, and characteristic 4–6 Hz spike-wave on EEG.
• Attacks not precipitated by sudden movement, and dystonia is absent.

• PRRT2 mutations often co-present with benign familial infantile seizures and migraine.
• A normal ictal EEG during paroxysmal events rules out epileptic myoclonus.
• Low-dose carbamazepine achieves rapid remission in PKD, guiding both diagnosis and treatment.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing PKD with exercise-induced dyskinesia – focus on trigger timing and duration.
2. Misdiagnosing dystonic posturing as epileptic tonic seizure – always obtain video-EEG.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. Movement Disorder Society Evidence-Based Guideline (2017):
• Recommendation: Carbamazepine is first-line for PKD (Level A).
2. European Federation of Neurological Societies Rare Movement Disorders Guideline (2014):
• Recommendation: Genetic testing for PRRT2 in familial PKD (Level B).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

PKD arises from transient dysfunction in the cortico-striato-pallido-thalamo-cortical loop, particularly aberrant GABAergic and glutamatergic modulation in the putamen.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

PRRT2 encodes a presynaptic protein that regulates voltage-gated calcium channels; its loss leads to increased neuronal excitability and paroxysmal dysregulation of basal ganglia output.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Detailed history of trigger and duration
2. Video-EEG to exclude epilepsy
3. Trial of low-dose carbamazepine for both diagnostic and therapeutic confirmation
4. Genetic testing for PRRT2 mutations if familial

Neuroimaging Pearls

Brain MRI is typically normal, but should be obtained to exclude structural lesions if atypical features present.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Carbamazepine 50–200 mg/day divided yields >90% resolution; titrate slowly to avoid drowsiness and hyponatremia. Alternative: phenytoin, oxcarbazepine.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 1 2020 exam. Paroxysmal dyskinesias are frequently tested by asking about specific triggers, genetic mutations, and treatment responses.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2022] Parkinson’s disease motor symptoms arise from dopaminergic neuron loss in the substantia nigra pars compacta, disrupting basal ganglia direct/indirect pathways. Levodopa’s short half-life causes pulsatile stimulation:
• Wearing-off phenomenon: end-of-dose akinesia due to falling plasma levels.
• Peak-dose dyskinesia: excessive synaptic dopamine at Cmax.
Management escalates from dose adjustments and adjunctive pharmacotherapy (COMT inhibitors, amantadine) to surgical therapies (DBS) when fluctuations/dyskinesias are disabling.

Evidence-Based Analysis

DBS of the subthalamic nucleus (STN) or globus pallidus interna (GPi) is indicated for advanced PD with motor complications refractory to optimized medical therapy. The 2016 AAN guideline (Level A evidence) endorses DBS for patients with >5-year disease duration, significant levodopa response, and motor fluctuations despite best medical management. The EARLYSTIM trial (Schüpbach et al. NEJM 2013) demonstrated superior quality-of-life and motor benefit with STN-DBS versus medical therapy in patients with early motor complications. Meta-analyses (Weaver et al. 2009; Follett et al. 2010) confirm ~50% reduction in “off” time and dyskinesias post-DBS.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Add Artane
• Anticholinergic (trihexyphenidyl) primarily improves tremor in younger PD patients.
• No proven effect on motor fluctuations or peak-dose dyskinesias; high risk of confusion in elderly.
B. Decrease levodopa and increase interval
• Worsens wearing-off by prolonging time between doses; unlike dose fractionation or pharmacokinetic smoothing.
C. Deep brain stimulation (DBS) [CORRECT]
• See Evidence-Based Analysis.
D. Rescue injection
• Apomorphine injection treats sudden “off” periods, not peak-dose dyskinesia or chronic wearing-off patterns.

Clinical Pearls

• Ideal DBS candidates: disease duration ≥5 y, significant levodopa response, disabling fluctuations/dyskinesia, absence of dementia/psychiatric contraindications.
• Amantadine is first-line for peak-dose dyskinesia but was not an option here; DBS offers long-term control.
• Pre-DBS workup: neuropsychological testing, brain MRI, multidisciplinary evaluation.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating increased dosing interval with reduced “off” time—in fact, dose fractionation or shorter intervals are needed.
2. Overuse of anticholinergics in elderly PD, leading to cognitive decline without improving fluctuations.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• American Academy of Neurology (2016): DBS is Level A recommended for advanced PD with motor complications not controlled by medications.
• Movement Disorder Society (MDS) Evidence-Based Review (2018): Supports STN/GPi-DBS for reducing “off” time and dyskinesia (Level I evidence).
• EARLYSTIM trial (Schüpbach et al. NEJM 2013): Early STN-DBS improves quality of life and motor outcomes versus best medical therapy in patients with recent motor complications (Class I evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

DBS electrodes target the STN or GPi, modulating pathological oscillatory activity in the basal ganglia-thalamocortical circuit and restoring balance between direct and indirect pathways.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Chronic intermittent levodopa dosing induces maladaptive plasticity: dopamine receptor sensitization and aberrant glutamatergic transmission in the striatum, manifesting as peak-dose dyskinesia; fluctuating synaptic dopamine causes wearing-off.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

DBS delivers high-frequency stimulation, inhibiting hyperactive nuclei output. Parameters (frequency, amplitude, pulse width) are titrated postoperatively; battery and hardware maintenance are critical considerations.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2022 exam. Management of advanced PD motor complications is commonly tested, often contrasting medical optimization versus surgical interventions.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Sydenham chorea is an autoimmune-mediated movement disorder following group A streptococcal infection.
• Pathophysiology: Molecular mimicry leads to antineuronal antibodies targeting the basal ganglia.
• Neuroanatomy: Dysfunction of the caudate and putamen in the striatum disrupts the indirect pathway, producing choreiform movements.
• Clinical: Onset weeks after pharyngitis in children/adolescents with abrupt, involuntary, non‐rhythmic movements, hypotonia, emotional lability.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Haloperidol, a potent D2 receptor antagonist, is first-line symptomatic therapy for moderate-to-severe Sydenham chorea. The 2015 American Heart Association guidelines (Class IIa, Level C) endorse haloperidol based on multiple case series showing 50–70% reduction in chorea severity within 1–2 weeks (Cardoso & de Souza, 2016). Haloperidol normalizes dopaminergic overactivity in striatal circuits. Valproic acid is considered second-line when neuroleptics are contraindicated or poorly tolerated.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Valproic acid
• Reason incorrect: Second-line agent; slower onset and less evidence than haloperidol.
• Misconception: All GABAergic modulators are equally effective for chorea.
• Differentiator: Primarily augments GABA, not dopaminergic blockade.

C. Carbamazepine
• Reason incorrect: Effective in paroxysmal dyskinesias, not chorea.
• Misconception: Broad-spectrum antiepileptics treat all hyperkinesias.
• Differentiator: Acts on Na+ channels; minimal effect on dopamine-mediated movements.

D. Prednisone
• Reason incorrect: Immunomodulator for severe/refractory cases, not first-line for symptom control.
• Misconception: Immediate suppression of chorea by steroids.
• Differentiator: Targets inflammation; symptom relief is delayed (weeks).

Clinical Pearls

- Always institute long-term penicillin prophylaxis to prevent recurrence.
• Baseline ECG before haloperidol to monitor QTc prolongation.
• In mild cases, valproic acid may be preferred to avoid extrapyramidal side effects.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Relying solely on immunotherapy (e.g., steroids) for rapid symptom relief.
2. Assuming all antiepileptics (e.g., carbamazepine) are equally effective for chorea.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- American Heart Association (2015): Recommends haloperidol for symptomatic control in Sydenham chorea (Class IIa, Level C).
• European League Against Rheumatism (EULAR, 2018): Advises immunomodulation (prednisone or IVIG) only for severe or refractory chorea (Level of Evidence 2).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Sydenham chorea arises from antibody-mediated dysfunction in the striatum (caudate nucleus and putamen), disrupting the indirect pathway and leading to decreased inhibition of thalamocortical projections.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Streptococcal M-protein antibodies cross-react with neuronal gangliosides via molecular mimicry. This triggers basal ganglia inflammation and impaired neurotransmitter balance (↑ dopamine relative to GABA).

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical evaluation: chorea, emotional lability, history of rheumatic fever.
2. Laboratory: ASO and anti-DNase B titers, ESR/CRP.
3. Cardiac: Echocardiography to assess for rheumatic carditis.
4. Exclude other causes: SLE, Wilson’s disease, drug-induced chorea.

Neuroimaging Pearls

Routine MRI/CT is typically normal; imaging is used to rule out structural lesions (e.g., stroke).

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Haloperidol: start 0.5–1 mg/day in children, titrate by 0.05 mg/kg every 6–8 h. Monitor for extrapyramidal symptoms; consider benztropine prophylaxis.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2021 exam. Sydenham chorea is often tested in rheumatology and movement-disorder blocks, emphasizing the distinction between symptomatic neuroleptic therapy versus immunomodulation.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2018] In cervical dystonia, sustained involuntary contractions of neck muscles (e.g., sternocleidomastoid, splenius capitis) lead to abnormal head postures. Botulinum toxin type A acts at the presynaptic terminal by cleaving SNAP-25, blocking acetylcholine release and inducing focal muscle relaxation. However, local diffusion of toxin into adjacent muscles—particularly the pharyngeal constrictors and cricopharyngeus—underlies off-target adverse events. Understanding the three-dimensional anatomy of the neck, the neuromuscular junction blockade mechanism, and factors that influence toxin spread (dose, volume, injection technique) is essential to optimize efficacy and minimize complications such as dysphagia, muscle weakness, dry mouth, and injection-site discomfort.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Dysphagia is the dose-limiting toxicity and most frequently reported adverse effect of botulinum toxin A in cervical dystonia. In the pivotal randomized trial by Comella et al. (Mov Disord 2005), onabotulinumtoxinA recipients experienced dysphagia in 17% versus 5% with placebo. A systematic review by Otte et al. (J Neurol 2018) found an aggregate dysphagia incidence of 15–20%. The American Academy of Neurology Practice Guideline (2016) assigns Level A evidence to onabotulinumtoxinA for cervical dystonia, noting dysphagia rates of 10–19% across trials. Mechanistically, diffusion from the injection site in the sternocleidomastoid or splenius capitis to the pharyngeal constrictor complex accounts for swallowing impairment. Techniques such as EMG or ultrasound guidance and conservative dosing mitigate but do not eliminate this risk.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Muscle weakness
• Although localized muscle weakness at the injection site is an expected pharmacological effect, it is reported less often as a patient-perceived adverse event than dysphagia.
• Misconception: equating therapeutic weakness with unintended spread; however, most weakness remains confined.

C. Dry mouth
• Botulinum toxin does not directly block salivary gland acetylcholine release in focal dystonia injections; dry mouth rates are <5%.
• Misconception: attributing systemic anticholinergic effects to a locally acting neurotoxin.

D. Localized pain at the injection site
• Needle discomfort occurs but is brief (hours) and reported in ~3–10%, lower than dysphagia rates in controlled trials.
• Misconception: overestimating mechanical pain versus neurotoxin diffusion effects.

Clinical Pearls

• Employ EMG or ultrasound guidance when injecting sternocleidomastoid to reduce toxin spread to pharyngeal muscles.
• Initiate with conservative dosing (≤100 U in sternocleidomastoid) and titrate based on clinical response and side effects.
• Pre- and post-injection swallow assessment identifies early dysphagia and guides dose adjustments.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing intended focal muscle weakness with off-target dysphagia—students may believe weakness at the target muscle is the predominant complaint.
2. Attributing systemic anticholinergic side effects (e.g., dry mouth) to botulinum toxin when its action is localized.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. American Academy of Neurology Practice Guideline (2016): “OnabotulinumtoxinA is established as first-line therapy for cervical dystonia (Level A); dysphagia is the most common adverse event (10–19%).”
2. European Federation of Neurological Societies (EFNS) Guidelines (2011): recommend EMG guidance to minimize dysphagia (Level B evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The sternocleidomastoid lies anterolateral to the pharyngeal constrictor complex; diffusion into the cricopharyngeus and middle constrictor can impair upper esophageal sphincter function, producing dysphagia.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Botulinum toxin’s heavy chain binds SV2 receptors on cholinergic terminals, is endocytosed, and its light chain cleaves SNAP-25, halting synaptic vesicle fusion and acetylcholine release. Off-target uptake by nearby pharyngeal motor endplates causes swallowing dysfunction.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

• Typical onabotulinumtoxinA dosing: 100–300 U per session across multiple neck muscles, repeated every 12–16 weeks.
• Dilution volume and injection speed influence diffusion; smaller aliquots and slower injection reduce spread.
• Alternative formulations (incobotulinumtoxinA, abobotulinumtoxinA) have similar dysphagia profiles when dose-normalized.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2018 exam. Adverse effects of botulinum toxin—especially dysphagia—are routinely tested on neurology boards as a high-yield fact.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2020] Essential tremor (ET) is a high‐frequency (4–12 Hz) action tremor affecting the upper limbs symmetrically. Tremors can be postural (holding a posture) or kinetic (during movement). In contrast, rest tremors occur when muscles are supported against gravity, and intention tremors emerge near a target. Alcohol responsiveness in ET is thought to reflect modulation of GABAergic tone in the cerebellothalamocortical circuitry. Accurate tremor classification hinges on frequency measurement, activation conditions, symmetry, and response to interventions.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Essential tremor is confirmed by 1) action/postural tremor at 4–12 Hz, 2) bilateral symmetry, and 3) consistent improvement with small doses of ethanol. The American Academy of Neurology (AAN) practice parameter (2018) assigns Level A evidence for propranolol and primidone in ET, noting a mean tremor amplitude reduction >50% in randomized trials (Koller et al., Neurology 1984). Genetic linkage studies (LINGO1 variant) support an autosomal‐dominant inheritance in ~50% of cases. Neurophysiological recordings localize oscillatory activity to the inferior olive–cerebellar–thalamic loop (Raethjen & Deuschl, Lancet Neurol 2012). Functional imaging (PET/SPECT) demonstrates increased cerebellar blood flow, distinguishing ET from basal ganglia hypofunction in Parkinson’s disease.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Enhanced physiological tremor
• Incorrect because its amplitude is low, frequency overlap exists (8–12 Hz) but it does not improve with alcohol.
• Misconception: equating any 10 Hz tremor with ET without considering symptomatic improvement or family history.
• Differentiator: Enhanced physiological tremor worsens with adrenergic stimuli (e.g., caffeine) and improves with β-blockers, not alcohol.

C. Parkinsonian tremor
• Incorrect because parkinsonian tremor is a 4–6 Hz rest tremor that diminishes with voluntary movement.
• Misconception: assuming all adult tremors are parkinsonian.
• Differentiator: Presence of bradykinesia, rigidity, and dopamine transporter deficit on DAT-SPECT.

D. Cerebellar intention tremor
• Incorrect because intention tremor is low frequency (<5 Hz), high amplitude, and appears only during target‐directed movement.
• Misconception: confusing all cerebellar signs with ET.
• Differentiator: Accompanied by dysmetria and dysdiadochokinesia, absent alcohol responsiveness.

- A positive family history in ~50% of ET cases suggests an autosomal‐dominant trait (LINGO1 involvement).
• Low‐dose alcohol transiently improves ET by enhancing GABA_A receptor function in the cerebellum.
• First‐line pharmacotherapy: propranolol (1–2 mg/kg/day) or primidone (up to 250 mg/day titrated).

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Overdiagnosing Parkinson’s disease in patients with purely action tremor and no bradykinesia.
• Relying solely on tremor frequency without assessing activation conditions and alcohol response.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AAN Practice Parameter on ET Management (Zesiewicz et al., Neurology 2018): Propranolol and primidone receive Level A recommendation; botulinum toxin for head/voice tremor (Level B).
• MDS‐ES/EFNS Evidence-Based Guideline (Hügel et al., Mov Disord 2019): Deep Brain Stimulation of the ventral intermedius nucleus (VIM–DBS) recommended (Level B) for medically refractory ET.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

ET arises from pathological oscillations within the inferior olive → cerebellar Purkinje cells → dentate nucleus → thalamic ventral intermediate nucleus → motor cortex loop.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Degeneration or aberrant firing in cerebellar Purkinje cells leads to reverberant oscillations in cerebello‐thalamo‐cortical circuits, producing rhythmic kinetic tremor.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Characterize tremor frequency with accelerometry.
2. Determine activation: rest vs postural vs intention.
3. Trial low‐dose ethanol (0.5 gm/kg) under supervision.
4. Exclude secondary causes (thyroid, medications).
5. Initiate first‐line therapy (propranolol/primidone).

Neuroimaging Pearls

Standard MRI is typically normal. Functional PET/SPECT may show increased cerebellar metabolism; DAT-SPECT is normal in ET (abnormal in Parkinson’s).

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Propranolol: nonselective β-blocker, start 40 mg BID, max 320 mg/day.
• Primidone: barbiturate, start 12.5–25 mg HS, titrate to 250 mg/day.
• Refractory: topiramate, gabapentin, VIM-DBS.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 1 2020 exam. Essential tremor vignettes recur frequently, often testing tremor frequency, activation posture versus rest, symmetry, and alcohol responsiveness.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2024] Orthostatic tremor (OT) is a rare movement disorder marked by a high‐frequency (13–18 Hz) tremor of the lower limbs occurring on standing and relieved by walking or sitting. Core concepts include:
• Neurophysiology: A central oscillator generates rapid, rhythmic muscle discharges.
• Electrophysiology: Surface EMG is required to detect the characteristic 13–18 Hz bursts.
• Clinical differentiation: Unlike parkinsonian freezing or cerebellar ataxia, OT-induced gait hesitation improves with ambulation.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Surface EMG (as part of NCS/EMG) is the diagnostic gold standard for OT, revealing synchronous 13–18 Hz discharges in leg muscles during stance. Jankovic and Azoulai (1994) first delineated this electrophysiological signature. The International Parkinson and Movement Disorder Society’s 2018 consensus on tremor classification endorses EMG for OT confirmation (Level C evidence). Brain MRI is typically normal in primary OT and is reserved for excluding structural mimics when other signs suggest a lesion. Dopamine transporter (DAT) scans assess nigrostriatal integrity and are indicated for parkinsonian syndromes, not OT. Empiric levodopa trials lack efficacy in OT, as its pathophysiology does not involve dopaminergic deficits; observational series have shown no sustained benefit.

Incorrect Options Analysis

• Brain MRI
– Incorrect: Primary OT shows no structural abnormalities; MRI yields no diagnostic findings.
– Misconception: Believing OT is due to a focal lesion rather than a neurophysiological tremor.
– Differentiator: MRI evaluates anatomy; EMG assesses tremor frequency.

• Dopamine transporter (DAT) scan
– Incorrect: DAT imaging is specific for parkinsonism with nigrostriatal degeneration, not OT.
– Misconception: Equating any gait disorder with a dopaminergic deficit.
– Differentiator: OT patients have normal DAT uptake; parkinsonian disorders show reduced uptake.

• Trial of levodopa
– Incorrect: Levodopa does not ameliorate OT, as confirmed by multiple case series.
– Misconception: Assuming all tremors respond to dopaminergic therapy.
– Differentiator: OT responds to GABAergic agents (e.g., clonazepam), not dopaminergic agents.

Clinical Pearls

• A high-frequency leg tremor on standing that abates with walking is pathognomonic for OT.
• Surface EMG is mandatory—clinical exam alone cannot reliably detect 13–18 Hz tremor.
• Clonazepam is first-line for symptomatic relief, reducing tremor amplitude and improving stability.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Misdiagnosing OT-induced “wobbliness” as orthostatic hypotension, leading to inappropriate cardiovascular workup.
2. Empiric use of DAT scans or levodopa for any hesitant gait, delaying definitive EMG-based diagnosis.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. International Parkinson and Movement Disorder Society (MDS) Consensus – Tremor Classification, Movement Disorders 2018: Recommends surface EMG to confirm OT (Level C evidence).
2. Cochrane Database Systematic Review on Orthostatic Tremor Pharmacotherapy 2019: Supports clonazepam as the preferred symptomatic treatment (Level B evidence).

This question appeared in Part 2 2024 exam. On board examinations, orthostatic tremor is most often tested as a vignette emphasizing high-frequency tremor on standing with EMG confirmation as the diagnostic key, distinguishing OT from parkinsonian and cerebellar gait disorders.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2020] Orthostatic tremor is a rare hyperkinetic movement disorder defined by a rapid (13–18 Hz) leg tremor elicited exclusively on standing, producing a sensation of “shaky legs” and unsteadiness. This tremor arises from pathological synchronization within the cerebello-thalamo-cortical oscillator network, leading to high-frequency, rhythmic muscle bursts on surface EMG. Ambulation or leaning typically abolishes the tremor, distinguishing it from other standing-induced hyperkinesias. Conventional neuroimaging is usually unremarkable, making electrophysiological confirmation essential. Clinicians should recognize the hallmark combination of leg tremor frequency and postural unsteadiness to differentiate orthostatic tremor from parkinsonian, essential, or myoclonic disorders.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Option B is correct because orthostatic tremor’s diagnostic criteria require both subjective unsteadiness on standing and an EMG-confirmed high-frequency (13–18 Hz) leg tremor. The Movement Disorder Society’s 2018 consensus on tremor classification mandates surface EMG demonstrating 13–18 Hz activity for primary orthostatic tremor (Bhatia et al., 2018; Level C evidence). Gerschlager et al. (Neurology, 2004) evaluated 28 patients, reporting a mean tremor frequency of 17 Hz with near-complete resolution upon walking, underscoring the “orthostatic” trigger. Neurophysiological studies (Brown et al., J Physiol, 2001) implicate hyper-synchronous oscillations within the cerebello-thalamo-cortical circuit as the tremor generator. The 2017 EFNS guidelines recommend clonazepam (0.5–2 mg/day) as first-line therapy, achieving ≥50% amplitude reduction in observational cohorts (EFNS, 2017; Level IV evidence).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. It improves with walking.
• Although tremor amplitude often decreases when patients begin ambulating, this feature alone is neither unique nor sufficient for diagnosis and may overlap with orthostatic myoclonus. The defining criterion remains EMG-confirmed high-frequency tremor on standing.

C. The typical onset is in the sixth decade of life.
• Epidemiological cohorts report a mean onset age of 60–65 years (seventh decade), not predominantly in the 50–59 age range. Gerschlager et al. found a mean onset of 63 ± 10 years.

D. It is associated with resting tremor and bradykinesia
• Resting tremor and bradykinesia are cardinal features of Parkinson disease. Orthostatic tremor lacks parkinsonian signs, presenting solely with a postural, high-frequency tremor.

Clinical Pearls

- Surface EMG demonstrating 13–18 Hz coherence between bilateral leg muscles is the gold standard for diagnosis.
• Clonazepam (0.5–2 mg/day) is first-line; gabapentin and primidone are second-line with variable efficacy.
• In refractory cases, thalamic deep brain stimulation targeting the ventral intermediate nucleus may provide benefit.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Conflating orthostatic tremor with essential tremor or parkinsonian tremor due to overlapping postural features.
2. Overreliance on clinical observation without EMG, leading to misdiagnosis as functional “shaky legs” or cerebellar ataxia.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- Movement Disorder Society Consensus on Tremor Classification (Bhatia KP et al., 2018): Defines primary orthostatic tremor by EMG-confirmed 13–18 Hz tremor on standing (Level C).
• EFNS Guidelines on Management of Tremor Disorders (2017): Recommend clonazepam 0.5–2 mg/day as first-line symptomatic therapy for orthostatic tremor (Grade C, Level IV evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Orthostatic tremor originates from pathological oscillations in the cerebello-thalamo-cortical network; the inferior olive and fastigial nucleus may serve as central pacemakers, projecting through the ventrolateral thalamus to motor cortex, synchronizing spinal motor neuron discharge.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Abnormal hyper-synchronization of group Ia afferent inputs and central oscillators generates rhythmic 13–18 Hz bursts. Unlike essential tremor (cerebellar Purkinje cell degeneration) or parkinsonian tremor (basal ganglia dysfunction), orthostatic tremor reflects a unique circuit-level oscillopathy triggered by postural afferent feedback.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Detailed history: leg “shaking” on standing, relief when walking.
2. Physical exam: observe high-frequency leg tremor on standing.
3. Surface EMG: confirm 13–18 Hz tremor frequency.
4. Exclude parkinsonism (no bradykinesia/rigidity) and myoclonus (jerk-like).
5. Rule out secondary causes with MRI if atypical.
6. Initiate clonazepam trial.

Neuroimaging Pearls

Routine MRI is usually normal; functional PET may show increased cerebellar activity but is not required for diagnosis. Imaging is reserved to exclude structural lesions in atypical presentations.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Clonazepam: start 0.25 mg at bedtime, titrate to 1–2 mg/day; monitor for sedation.
• Gabapentin: 300 mg TID, may offer adjunctive benefit.
• Primidone: up to 250 mg/day; less robust data.
• Deep brain stimulation of the VIM nucleus: considered for severely refractory cases.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2022] Orthostatic tremor is characterized by a high-frequency (13–18 Hz) tremor of weight-bearing limbs upon standing, producing unsteadiness and “shaky legs,” often described as dizziness or imbalance.
1. Neural oscillator: A central tremor generator in the cerebello-thalamo-cortical network discharges at ~15 Hz only when antigravity muscles are engaged.
2. Electrophysiology: Surface EMG during standing reveals rhythmic, synchronous bursts in leg muscles that abate when sitting or walking.
3. Therapeutic targets: Enhancement of GABAergic inhibition dampens this high-frequency activity, improving stability and reducing symptoms.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Clonazepam, a benzodiazepine potentiating GABA_A receptors, is first-line for orthostatic tremor. Multiple case series (Gerschlager et al., 2004; Erro et al., 2015) demonstrate symptomatic improvement in >70% of patients at doses of 0.5–4 mg/day. The International Parkinson and Movement Disorder Society (MDS) consensus statement (2018) grades clonazepam as Level B evidence for orthostatic tremor. By enhancing inhibitory neurotransmission in cerebellothalamic circuits, it suppresses the 13–18 Hz oscillator. No randomized controlled trials exist, but consistent open-label reports support its efficacy and tolerability.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Propranolol
• Ineffective in orthostatic tremor despite utility in essential tremor.
• Misconception: All action tremors respond to β-blockade.
• Differentiator: Essential tremor is 4–12 Hz and responsive to propranolol; orthostatic tremor is faster and centrally driven.

C. Lamotrigine
• No evidence for benefit; targets voltage-gated sodium channels, not GABAergic pathways.
• Misconception: All antiepileptics are interchangeable for tremor control.
• Differentiator: Agents like primidone or clonazepam have proven GABAergic modulation in tremor.

D. Deep brain stimulation (DBS)
• Reserved for refractory cases after maximal medical therapy; targeting VIM nucleus occasionally reported in case studies with mixed outcomes.
• Misconception: DBS is first-line for any disabling tremor.
• Differentiator: Invasive, with surgical risks; not standard initial therapy for orthostatic tremor.

Clinical Pearls

- Always perform weight-bearing EMG for suspected orthostatic tremor; clinical exam alone may be misleading.
• Clonazepam often causes morning sedation; administer at bedtime and titrate gradually.
• Distinguish orthostatic tremor from sensory ataxia—neurographic testing and Romberg sign help differentiate.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Mislabeling orthostatic tremor as cerebellar ataxia due to gait unsteadiness—lack of cerebellar signs and EMG differentiate.
2. Empiric trial of propranolol before confirming tremor frequency—therapeutic misstep delays correct treatment.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- MDS Evidence-Based Review (2018): Recommends clonazepam as first-line (Level B) for orthostatic tremor.
• European Academy of Neurology Guideline on Tremor (2018): Classifies orthostatic tremor as a distinct entity and endorses benzodiazepines; cites open-label series.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Orthostatic tremor arises from hyperfunctional oscillatory loops in the posterior fossa. Aberrant oscillations in cerebellar Purkinje cells propagate via the dentato-thalamic pathway, synchronized by GABAergic interneuron dysfunction, manifesting only under antigravity load.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Suspect in patients reporting immediate unsteadiness/dizziness on standing.
2. Perform surface EMG of tibialis anterior/quadricpes while standing; look for 13–18 Hz bursts.
3. Exclude other tremors (essential, cerebellar) by frequency and clinical context.
4. Initiate clonazepam; reassess symptom control and side effects.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Clonazepam: start 0.25 mg HS, increase by 0.25–0.5 mg every 3–5 days to a maximum of ~4 mg/day. Monitor for sedation, tolerance, and withdrawal. Consider adjunctive gabapentin if clonazepam insufficient.

Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2018] Orthostatic tremor is a rare, high-frequency (13–18 Hz) tremor of the legs exclusively upon standing, reflecting abnormal oscillatory activity in cerebello-thalamocortical loops. Unlike essential tremor (4–12 Hz) or Parkinsonian tremor (4–6 Hz), patients feel unsteady rather than visibly shaking. Definitive diagnosis requires surface EMG confirmation of synchronous, high-frequency discharges in weight-bearing leg muscles. First-line therapy modulates GABAergic neurotransmission to dampen the central oscillator responsible for the tremor.

(Word count: 118)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Clonazepam, a long-acting benzodiazepine, enhances GABA_A–mediated inhibition in the cerebello-thalamo-cortical network, reducing tremor amplitude and frequency in orthostatic tremor. Multiple small trials (e.g., Köller et al., 2000) and practice guidelines from the Movement Disorder Society (MDS Clinical Practice Recommendation, 2021) rate clonazepam as first-line (Level B evidence). Gabapentin may help via presynaptic GABA release but shows lower efficacy (Level C). Propranolol targets beta-adrenergic mechanisms in limb-postural tremor (essential tremor) and is ineffective in the central oscillator of orthostatic tremor. Levodopa addresses dopaminergic deficits in Parkinson’s disease and does not impact non-parkinsonian tremors.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Propranolol
• Reason incorrect: Blocks peripheral β-receptors; effective in essential tremor but not in high-frequency central oscillators.
• Misconception: Equating any standing tremor with essential tremor.
• Differentiation: Orthostatic tremor persists despite walking; essential tremor improves with movement.

B. Levodopa
• Reason incorrect: Repletes striatal dopamine; indicated for Parkinsonian rest tremor (4–6 Hz), not for orthostatic tremor.
• Misconception: All tremors respond to dopaminergic therapy.
• Differentiation: Orthostatic tremor EMG frequency >12 Hz; Parkinson’s tremor EMG <7 Hz and occurs at rest.

D. Gabapentin
• Reason incorrect: Modulates GABA release; some benefit in orthostatic tremor but less robust and second-line.
• Misconception: Assuming all GABAergic agents are equally effective.
• Differentiation: Gabapentin’s effect is dose-dependent and often insufficient as monotherapy.

Clinical Pearls

1. Orthostatic tremor feels like “unsteady rocking” rather than visible shaking; patients may lean on furniture to suppress it.
2. Always confirm suspected orthostatic tremor with weight-bearing EMG showing 13–18 Hz bursts—clinical exam alone may mimic sensory ataxia.
3. Initiate clonazepam at low dose (0.5 mg nightly), titrating upward to minimize sedation while achieving tremor control.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Mislabeling orthostatic tremor as essential tremor: essential tremor improves with action and is lower frequency.
2. Overreliance on propranolol for all tremor types, leading to treatment failure in central tremors like orthostatic tremor.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- Movement Disorder Society Clinical Practice Recommendation on Tremor, 2021: Recommends clonazepam as first-line for orthostatic tremor (Level B).
• European Academy of Neurology/European Federation of Neurological Societies Guideline, 2019: Endorses benzodiazepines over other agents for orthostatic tremor (Level C).

[Exam: Part II 2019] Essential palatal myoclonus (EPM) is a focal, rhythmic contraction of the soft palate—predominantly tensor veli palatini—without an identifiable structural lesion on neuroimaging. Patients often perceive an audible “click” as the eustachian tube opens. In contrast, symptomatic palatal myoclonus (SPM) results from lesions in the dentate–olivary–red nucleus (Guillain–Mollaret) triangle (e.g., stroke, demyelination) and shows hypertrophic olivary degeneration on MRI. Recognizing EPM versus SPM prevents unnecessary investigations and tailors management toward symptomatic relief (e.g., botulinum toxin, clonazepam for EPM) rather than lesion-directed therapy.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Option D (Family history) is correct. Although most EPM cases are sporadic, approximately 10–15% have a positive family history, suggesting genetic predisposition (Frucht SJ et al., J Neurol 2015). EPM patients have normal brain MRI and present with characteristic ear clicks due to tensor veli palatini contractions. No structural lesions are identified. In contrast, SPM is always secondary to identifiable lesions (stroke, tumor, demyelination) with MRI evidence of hypertrophic olivary degeneration (Kim JS et al., Neurology 2012). Family history distinguishes idiopathic EPM from SPM.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Most likely due to stroke
• Incorrect: Stroke causes SPM, not EPM.
• Misconception: Equating any palatal myoclonus with cerebrovascular events.
• Differentiator: EPM has normal MRI; SPM shows lesion.

B. Symptomatic palatal myoclonus
• Incorrect: Denotes secondary myoclonus from structural lesions.
• Misconception: Belief that “symptomatic” and “essential” are interchangeable.
• Differentiator: EPM is idiopathic; SPM has identifiable pathology.

C. Essential palatal myoclonus
• Incorrect: This repeats the disease entity rather than an associated feature.
• Misconception: Circular reasoning/tokenism.
• Differentiator: Association questions require a distinct clinical or etiologic feature.

Clinical Pearls

- EPM often presents with an audible click as the tensor veli palatini briefly opens the eustachian tube.
• Hypertrophic olivary degeneration on T2‐weighted MRI is pathognomonic for SPM.
• Botulinum toxin A injections into tensor veli palatini provide targeted relief in EPM.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Mislabeling EPM as SPM when an ear click is misinterpreted as pathological tinnitus.
2. Over-reliance on negative imaging to exclude palatal myoclonus entirely rather than distinguishing EPM from SPM.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- American Academy of Neurology (AAN), Practice Parameter: Treatment of Myoclonus, Neurology 2016
Recommendation: Clonazepam (0.5–2 mg/day) and valproate (500–1500 mg/day) are first-line for focal myoclonus, including EPM (Level B).
• European Federation of Neurological Societies (EFNS), Guideline: Diagnosis and Management of Myoclonus, Eur J Neurol 2012
Recommendation: Botulinum toxin type A injection into palatal muscles is effective for EPM (Level C).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Lesions of the Guillain–Mollaret triangle (dentate nucleus → red nucleus → inferior olive) produce SPM with secondary olivary hypertrophy; EPM spares this pathway.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

- EPM: Hyperexcitability of peripheral palatal muscle stretch receptors leads to involuntary rhythmic contractions.
• SPM: Deafferentation‐induced trans-synaptic hypertrophy of the inferior olive generates rhythmic discharges.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical history: audible click vs other tinnitus.
2. Observe palatal contractions on exam.
3. MRI brainstem: normal in EPM, hypertrophic olivary degeneration in SPM.
4. Elicit family history: positive in EPM.
5. Classify as EPM vs SPM to guide management.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- T2 hyperintensity/enlargement of inferior olive → SPM.
• Clean MRI confirms EPM.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- First-line: clonazepam titrated to effect (0.5–2 mg/day) or valproate (500–1500 mg/day).
• Adjunct: botulinum toxin A injections into tensor veli palatini (10–25 MU per side).

[Exam: Part I 2024] Parkinson’s disease features dysfunction of basal ganglia–thalamocortical circuits due to nigrostriatal dopamine depletion.
1. The ventral intermediate nucleus (VIM) of the thalamus receives cerebellar input and is pivotal in tremor generation.
2. Lesioning (thalamotomy) or modulating (DBS) the VIM disrupts pathological oscillations underlying resting tremor.
3. Bradykinesia and rigidity arise predominantly from striatal and globus pallidus internus dysfunction, while postural instability involves broader brainstem and cerebellar networks.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Thalamotomy targets the VIM to abolish tremor by interrupting cerebellothalamocortical loops. Multiple case series and controlled trials (e.g., Deuschl et al., 2000, J. Neurol. Neurosurg. Psychiatry) demonstrate >70% reduction in contralateral PD tremor at one year, with minimal change in bradykinesia or rigidity. The Movement Disorder Society (MDS) Task Force on Tremor (2018) assigns Level A evidence for thalamic interventions improving refractory tremor. AAN guidelines (2019) also support MR-guided focused ultrasound thalamotomy (Level B) for medication-resistant tremor. In contrast, rigidity and bradykinesia respond best to dopaminergic therapy and GPi or STN targets, not VIM lesions.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Bradykinesia
• Thalamotomy spares nigrostriatal pathways responsible for movement initiation.
• Misconception: all PD motor signs improve with one surgical target.
• Bradykinesia improves with STN or GPi modulation, not VIM lesion.

C. Rigidity
• Rigidity involves increased pallidal–thalamic inhibition, requiring modulation at GPi/STN.
• Thalamic lesions do not alter muscle tone circuits significantly.

D. Postural instability
• Arises from complex brainstem and cerebellar integration; thalamic lesioning has no effect.
• Common error: attributing axial symptoms to the same pathway as limb tremor.

RigidityNo significant changeGPi/STN–thalamocortical motor pathways

Clinical Pearls

- Unilateral VIM thalamotomy yields contralateral tremor control; bilateral procedures risk dysarthria and ataxia.
• Deep brain stimulation (DBS) of VIM offers adjustability and lower permanent side-effect rates than lesioning.
• MR-guided focused ultrasound is a noninvasive thalamotomy option for medication-refractory tremor.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating tremor control with overall motor improvement—thalamotomy spares bradykinesia and rigidity.
2. Confusing lesion targets—pallidotomy (GPi) improves rigidity and bradykinesia, whereas thalamotomy (VIM) specifically ameliorates tremor.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. Movement Disorder Society Task Force on Tremor (2018): “Unilateral VIM thalamotomy is Level A effective for medication-resistant tremor in PD.”
2. American Academy of Neurology (AAN) Practice Guideline (2019): “MRgFUS thalamotomy provides Level B evidence for significant tremor reduction in PD patients intolerant of DBS.”

Neuroanatomical Correlations

- VIM nucleus: receives dentate nucleus input via superior cerebellar peduncle; projects to motor cortex.
• Lesion interrupts aberrant 4–6 Hz oscillatory activity characteristic of PD resting tremor.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

- Dopamine loss → disinhibition of STN → increased GPi output → altered thalamic firing patterns.
• Tremor arises from entrained oscillations between cerebellum and thalamus; targeted VIM lesion abolishes the pacemaker.

[Exam: Part 2 2020] Akathisia is a hyperkinetic movement disorder characterized by an inner sense of restlessness and a compelling need to move, often precipitated by dopamine-blocking agents. Key concepts:
• Basal ganglia circuitry: Nigrostriatal D2 blockade disrupts the direct/indirect pathways, provoking hyperactivity in motor output.
• Phenomenology: Akathisia presents as subjective restlessness with observable pacing or leg crossing, distinct from involuntary, dance-like choreiform movements or sustained dystonic postures.
• Medication‐induced movement disorders: Recognize temporal association with antipsychotic initiation or dose escalation.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Akathisia arises when antipsychotic D2 receptor occupancy in the striatum exceeds ~80%, leading to imbalance between GABAergic inhibitory and glutamatergic excitatory outputs in the external globus pallidus. The Barnes Akathisia Rating Scale (BARS) quantifies severity. Propranolol (30–80 mg/day) demonstrates level A evidence in randomized trials (Solmi et al., Eur Neuropsychopharmacol 2016) for symptom reduction. The American Psychiatric Association (APA) 2020 Schizophrenia Guideline recommends dose reduction or switching to a lower‐potency agent plus adjunctive beta-blockers (Level B). MRI/PET studies correlate resting striatal hypermetabolism with akathisia severity.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Chorea
• Incorrect because chorea produces irregular, non‐suppressible, dance-like movements without a subjective inner restlessness.
• Misconception: any hyperkinetic movement is chorea.
• Differentiator: chorea is involuntary and unpredictable; akathisia is a compulsion to move.

B. Dystonia
• Incorrect: dystonia features sustained muscle contractions causing twisting or abnormal postures, not constant pacing or leg crossing.
• Misconception: fidgeting equals dystonia.
• Differentiator: dystonia’s movements are patterned and may be painful.

D. Restless legs syndrome
• Incorrect: RLS involves unpleasant leg sensations predominantly at rest and at night, relieved by movement.
• Misconception: leg movement always indicates RLS.
• Differentiator: RLS has sensory symptoms and circadian pattern, akathisia is continuous and medication-related.

Clinical Pearls

• Akathisia can mimic agitation or anxiety—always assess for motor restlessness in patients on antipsychotics.
• Use the Barnes Akathisia Rating Scale for objective measurement.
• Propranolol is first-line; benzodiazepines or mirtazapine are alternatives if beta-blockers contraindicated.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Attributing akathisia to worsening psychiatric illness rather than a drug side effect, leading to antipsychotic dose escalation and symptom exacerbation.
2. Confusing akathisia with RLS—missing daytime restlessness without sensory discomfort.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. NICE CG178 (2014): Recommends beta-blockers (propranolol) as first-line for antipsychotic-induced akathisia (Level 1A).
2. APA Practice Guideline for the Treatment of Patients With Schizophrenia (2020): Advises dose reduction, switching antipsychotic, and adjunctive beta-blocker therapy for akathisia (Level B evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Akathisia stems from dopamine D2 receptor blockade in the striatum (putamen and caudate), disrupting indirect pathway inhibition and leading to increased pallidal GABAergic output and cortical hyperexcitability.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Antipsychotic-induced D2 occupancy >80% → imbalance in direct/indirect basal ganglia pathways → reduced thalamic inhibition → cortical motor overactivity manifesting as restlessness.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical history: onset related to antipsychotic initiation/dose change.
2. Symptom assessment: subjective restlessness vs true involuntary movements.
3. Physical exam: observe pacing, leg crossing, inability to sit.
4. Rating scale: Barnes Akathisia Rating Scale.
5. Rule out mimics: mood/anxiety disorders, RLS, Parkinson’s.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

• First-line: Propranolol 30–80 mg/day (divided doses).
• Alternatives: Mirtazapine 7.5–15 mg at bedtime, clonazepam 0.25–1 mg.
• Dose adjustment: Reduce or switch antipsychotic if feasible.

[Exam: Part II 2022] Progressive Supranuclear Palsy (PSP) is a tauopathy characterized by early postural instability, vertical gaze palsy, axial rigidity, and frontal executive dysfunction.
• Dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta project to the dorsal striatum; their loss underlies bradykinesia in parkinsonian syndromes.
• Levodopa replenishes striatal dopamine and can transiently ameliorate bradykinesia and rigidity if sufficient nigrostriatal neurons remain.
• Other PSP features—axial rigidity causing gait instability, supranuclear gaze palsy, autonomic dysfunction—stem from non-dopaminergic pathology (midbrain tegmentum, globus pallidus internus, brainstem nuclei) and do not improve with levodopa.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Bradykinesia in PSP reflects partial preservation of nigrostriatal pathways; up to 30% of patients demonstrate modest, transient improvement in bradykinesia and rigidity on high-dose levodopa (≤1.5 g/day) (Litvan et al., Movement Disorders Society PSP Criteria, 2017). Tremor is uncommon (<20%), reflecting pallidal rather than striatal dysfunction, and rarely responds. Gait instability in PSP is driven by axial rigidity and postural reflex impairment from midbrain and pontine lesions; levodopa shows no benefit (McFarland & Litvan, JNNP, 2016). Urinary incontinence arises from frontal cortical–pontine circuits and sacral autonomic nuclei degeneration—non-dopaminergic pathways. Clinical guidelines (EFNS/PNS 2018) recommend a levodopa trial for bradykinesia/rigidity but note limited efficacy.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Tremor
‒ PSP tremor is infrequent and often resembles postural or action tremor, arising from pallidal or cerebellar circuitry.
‒ Misconception: all Parkinsonism tremors are dopa-responsive.
‒ Unlike classic resting tremor in PD (striatal dopamine deficiency), PSP tremor mechanisms are non-dopa responsive.

C. Gait instability
‒ Early falls and postural instability in PSP reflect midbrain tegmentum and pedunculopontine nucleus degeneration.
‒ Misconception: gait freezing will improve with levodopa as in PD.
‒ Axial rigidity and impaired righting reflexes do not respond to dopaminergic therapy.

D. Urinary incontinence
‒ Caused by frontal lobe disconnection and sacral autonomic neuron loss.
‒ Misconception: autonomic features in parkinsonian syndromes respond to levodopa.
‒ Levodopa does not affect cholinergic parasympathetic pathways.
